<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Indicate by check mark if disclosure of delinquent filers pursuant to Item 405 of Regulation S-K is not contained herein, and will not be contained, to the best of Registrant&rsquo;s knowledge, in definitive proxy or
information statements incorporated by reference in Part III of this Form 10-K or any amendment to this Form 10-K.</font> <font color="black" face="Wingdings">&uml;</font></p>

<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Indicate by check mark whether the registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined in Rule 12b-2 of the Act).</font></p>

<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Yes</font> <font face="Wingdings">x</font> No <font color="black" face="Wingdings">&uml;</font></p>

<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The aggregate market value of the voting and non-voting common equity held by non-affiliates of KFx Inc. as of June 30, 2004, the last business day of KFx Inc.&rsquo;s most recently completed second fiscal quarter was
$106,773,000 computed by reference to the price at which KFx Inc.&rsquo;s common stock was last traded on that date, as reported on the American Stock Exchange.</font></p>

<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At March 4, 2005, 65,289,000 shares of common stock of the Registrant were outstanding.</font></p>

<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Documents Incorporated by Reference:</font></b></p>

<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The information required by Part III of this Report (Items 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14) is incorporated by reference to portions of KFx&rsquo;s proxy statement to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission within 120 days
of December 31, 2004 for our 2005 Annual Meeting.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">CAUTIONS ABOUT FORWARD LOOKING STATEMENTS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This Annual Report on Form 10-K includes forward-looking statements about events, products or financial performance that may not exist,
or may not have occurred.&nbsp; For example, statements like we &ldquo;expect,&rdquo; we &ldquo;believe,&rdquo; we &ldquo;plan,&rdquo; we &ldquo;intend&rdquo; or we &ldquo;anticipate&rdquo; are forward-looking statements.&nbsp; Investors should be aware that our
actual operating results and financial performance may differ materially from our expressed expectations because of risks and uncertainties about the future including risks related to economic and competitive conditions.&nbsp; In addition, we will not necessarily
update the information in this Annual Report on Form 10-K if any forward-looking statement later turns out to be inaccurate.&nbsp; Details about risks affecting various aspects of our business are included throughout this Form 10-K. Investors should read all of these
risks carefully, and should pay particular attention to risks affecting the following areas: competition issues discussed on page 11; government regulation discussed on pages 8 to 11; intellectual property and proprietary rights discussed on page 7; specific risk
factors discussed on pages 13 to 18; and commitments and contingent liabilities described in Note 15 to the financial statements included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.</font></p>

<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PART I</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In this Annual Report on Form 10-K, we use the terms &ldquo;KFx,&rdquo; &ldquo;we,&rdquo; &ldquo;our,&rdquo; and &ldquo;us&rdquo;
to refer to KFx Inc. and its subsidiaries.&nbsp; All references to K-Fuel, K-Fuel</font><sup><font size="2" color="black">&trade;</font></sup><font size="2" color="black">and K-Fuel Plus</font><sup><font size="2" color="black">&trade;</font></sup><font size="2"
color="black">refer to our patented process and technology explained in detail throughout this Annual Report on Form 10-K.&nbsp; All references to years, unless otherwise noted, refer to our fiscal year, which ends on December 31st.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our common stock is traded on the American Stock Exchange under the symbol &ldquo;KFX.&rdquo; Our principal executive office is located
at 55 Madison Street, Suite 745, Denver, Colorado 80206 and our telephone number is (303) 293-2992.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp; Our web site address is www.kfx.com.&nbsp; Through this web site, we make available, free of charge, on the Investor Info section of our web site our Annual Report on Form 10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q, Current
Reports on Form 8-K, and all amendments to those reports, as soon as reasonably practicable after these reports are electronically filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission.&nbsp; We also make available through our web site other reports filed
with the SEC under the Exchange Act, including our proxy statements and reports filed by officers and directors under Section 16(a) of that Act.&nbsp; We do not intend for information contained in our web site to be part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.</font></p>

<h5><a name="tx14120_1"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></h5>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">ITEM 1. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; BUSINESS</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">OVERVIEW</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; KFx is a &ldquo;clean coal&rdquo; company with a patented process and technology, which we refer to as K-Fuel technology,
that uses heat and pressure to physically and chemically transform coal with a lower heat value, as measured by British Thermal Units (or Btus) into coal with a higher heat value, while at the same time removing significant amounts of certain impurities, including
mercury, sulfur dioxide, or <font color="black">SO</font></font><sub><font size="2" color="black">2</font></sub><font size="2" color="black">,</font><font size="2">emissions of oxides of Nitrogen, or NOx.&nbsp; Throughout the Western United States there are
significant coal resources with heat values less than 9,000 Btus.&nbsp; Such heat values are considered low grade and serve as feedstocks for our process.&nbsp; Many coal-fired, electric generating units, or EGUs, which comprise our primary market, burn coal that is
11,000 Btus or greater.&nbsp; Our technology adds value for coal producers and the electric power generation industry by significantly improving the quality of lower-grade coal and facilitating its compliance with certain air emission standards.&nbsp; We believe the
current pricing of coal in the U.S. and the declining availability of cleaner, higher-Btu coal to comply with environmental regulation, referred to as compliance coal, has created a near-term and long-term opportunity for K-Fuel.&nbsp; Furthermore, certain federal
tax credits were enacted in 2004 to encourage the development of cleaner fuel sources.&nbsp; Based upon testing we have performed to date, we believe that K-Fuel meets the tax credit requirements of a refined coal and we believe our future plants that will produce
K-Fuel will be eligible for the credit if they are operational by January 1, 2009.&nbsp; Such credits add to the economic feasibility of processing and selling K-Fuel.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We continue to make significant headway toward the commercialization of our proprietary K-Fuel technology.&nbsp;
Among the key milestones we achieved in 2004 and in early 2005 were:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">

plant.</font></p>

crusher, related buildings, water disposal wells and about 500,000 tons of coal reserves.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We continue to advance the commercial viability of our patented K-Fuel technology through research and development, the operation of a
demonstration facility and most recently with the construction of a commercial-scale production plant.&nbsp; We have been developing the technology for approximately 20 years through a series of patents and modifications to</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 3</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">such patents.&nbsp; Our latest modification involved the use of Lurgi South Africa (Pty) Limited&rsquo;s and Sasol-Lurgi Technology Company (Pty) Limited proprietary equipment.&nbsp; See further discussion of our strategic
alliance with Sasol-Lurgi below.&nbsp; Traditionally, the Sasol-Lurgi equipment is used for coal gasification.&nbsp; We have modified this equipment for use with our K-Fuel technology and these changes have resulted in our application for a new patent.&nbsp; See
further discussion regarding our patents below in Patents and Trade Secrets.&nbsp; We believe the combination of the Sasol-Lurgi equipment with our technology will result in a cleaner, environmentally acceptable higher-grade fuel, which will be economical to produce
on a commercial scale.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, we operate a research, development, and demonstration facility near Gillette, Wyoming that includes a Class A laboratory
and pilot plants capable of processing small amounts of most types of source coal into K-Fuel using our proprietary technology.&nbsp; We refer to this lab and the pilot plants, collectively, as the demonstration facility.&nbsp; We maintain this demonstration facility
to provide complex technological data to our potential customers and governmental agencies in assessing the benefits of the K-Fuel process.&nbsp; Potential customers provide feedstock to us, which we process through our demonstration facility to determine if the
resultant K-Fuel meets their specifications, such as heat value, moisture content and amount of impurities.&nbsp; This facility does not contain Sasol-Lurgi equipment.&nbsp; However, it contains equipment that can replicate the processing environment of the
Sasol-Lurgi equipment, except on a smaller scale.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 2004, we began construction of a 750,000-tons per year plant in the Powder River Basin in Wyoming, which we refer to as the
750,000-ton plant.&nbsp; Sasol-Lurgi is providing, under a professional services agreement, the engineering, design and certain project management services for the process portion of this plant.&nbsp; The 750,000-ton plant is intended to demonstrate that the K-Fuel
process performs as expected on a commercial scale and will serve as a basis for larger plants.&nbsp; The equipment used in the K-Fuel process is modular in design, which makes it easy to expand.&nbsp; In fact, the 750,000-ton plant is expandable to a 8 million-tons
per year, which we expect to be the size of our typical commercial plant.&nbsp; Therefore, we believe that the 750,000-ton plant provides a model for larger plants, as the most important modification to increase the size of the plant is the addition of process
modules, the equipment that actually processes the coal.&nbsp; Construction is currently in process and expected to be completed during the summer of 2005.&nbsp; Throughout the fourth quarter of 2005, we anticipate testing, commissioning and initial commercial
production of the plant.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Currently, we operate our business in one segment.&nbsp; This segment primarily contains:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The majority of the assets associated with this segment are those related to the development and construction costs and equipment of
the 750,000-ton plant, cash and our patents.&nbsp; We currently manage our business in one segment as our operations are focused on demonstrating our technology and the commercial viability of our product.&nbsp; We entered into a licensing agreement with Cook Inlet
Coal, LLC in December 2004 and received $7.5 million in cash.&nbsp; See further discussion of the licensing agreement below in Other Development Activities.&nbsp; While we collected cash related to licensing and other insignificant activities, we do not yet believe
that our business has reached a level of complexity that would result in segment presentation.&nbsp; As a result, our results of operations are evaluated and allocations of capital resources are based upon the operations of one segment.&nbsp; In the future, we plan
to develop and operate K-Fuel production plants both domestically and internationally, both wholly owned and through joint ventures, as well as to license the K-Fuel technology to third parties.&nbsp; As our operations expand, we expect to increase the number of
segments under which we manage our business to reflect the increasing complexity of our operations.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We incorporated under the laws of the state of Delaware in 1988.&nbsp; Our financial statements include all of our wholly owned
subsidiaries, including Landrica Development Company, which was acquired in May 2004.&nbsp; During 2003, as a part of an exchange transaction with Kennecott Energy Company, we transferred our ownership of Pegasus Technologies, Inc. to Kennecott for its remaining
interest in K-Fuel LLC, or KFL, that we did not own.&nbsp; As a result of this exchange, we have accounted for Pegasus as a discontinued operation and have accordingly removed its effects from our results of continuing operations for 2003 and 2002.&nbsp; KFL is now a
wholly owned subsidiary.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">OUR K-FUEL PRODUCT AND OUR STRATEGY</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our K-Fuel technology has been evolving for approximately 20 years with the most recent modification incorporating the Sasol-Lurgi
proprietary coal processing equipment.&nbsp; Research and development is an iterative process that resulted in improvements in the K-Fuel product and often times reduced production costs.&nbsp;&nbsp; The following are some of the most important steps we have taken in
the development of the K-Fuel technology:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 4</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We identified opportunities for improvement in the production of K-Fuel through the operation of the plant we jointly owned with Thermo Ecotech Corporation.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our demonstration facility completed product testing by processing feedstock provided by potential customers to create K-Fuel, with positive results.&nbsp; This product testing also indicated areas for improvement.&nbsp; After
a through review of these areas, we made significant modifications at our demonstration facility that we believe will resolve these problems on a commercial scale.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We entered into a strategic alliance with Sasol-Lurgi to combine their proprietary equipment with our patented technology that further improved our process.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, our research and development costs were approximately $723,000, $1.6
million and $640,000, respectively.&nbsp; During 2004, we re-evaluated costs incurred and determined that costs related to technical and engineering services met the definition of research and development.&nbsp; As a result, we reclassified such costs incurred in
prior years to research and development to be consistent with our current year presentation.&nbsp; In addition, we indirectly incurred research and development costs related to our prior investment in KFL totaling approximately $92,000 and $54,000 in 2003 and 2002,
respectively.&nbsp; Our near-term strategy is to complete the construction of the 750,000-ton plant; identify potential sites for additional, larger facilities; obtain capital for further expansion; market our product to coal-fired EGUs and other potential
purchasers; identify and obtain feedstock contracts and negotiate transportation of K-Fuel.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The KFP Plant</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thermo Ecotek Corporation and KFx constructed a 500,000-ton per year K-Fuel production facility, or the KFP Plant, near Gillette,
Wyoming, using an older version of our K-Fuel technology.&nbsp; The KFP Plant operated and produced commercially salable K-Fuel in 1998 and 1999.&nbsp; In June 1999, however, Thermo Ecotek suspended all K-Fuel production at the KFP Plant, due to its strategic
restructuring.&nbsp; Thereafter, we sold our interest in the KFP Plant to Thermo Ecotek Corporation and in September 2002, the major equipment at the KFP Plant was purchased by a third party and removed from the site.&nbsp; The KFP Plant experienced certain problems
while operating, relating to tar and fines (small particulates of coal) build-up within the system during production and product quality issues related to product dusting.&nbsp; We believe we have resolved these issues by modifying the K-Fuel process using a more
uniform size of raw coal that will heat evenly, adjusting heat and pressure levels and utilizing the Sasol-Lurgi equipment, among other things.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Product Testing</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In late 2000, we conducted K-Fuel product testing for third parties using Powder River Basin coal, or PRB coal, as the feedstock.&nbsp;
PRB coal typically has among the lowest mercury content of any naturally available coal in the U.S.&nbsp; Analysis of the K-Fuel by-product produced during the test burn indicated that the K-Fuel products produced lower amounts of SO</font><sub><font size="2" color=
"black">2</font></sub><font size="2" color="black">, NOx, mercury and chlorine than untreated combusted PRB coal.&nbsp; Analysis of testing also indicated that an improved process could be designed to produce enhanced K-Fuel within potentially attractive economic
constraints, with improved reliability and have lower capital and operating costs than any previous K-Fuel plant design.&nbsp; The Btu value of the K-Fuel product tested was approximately 11,200 to 11,600 Btus per pound.&nbsp; Upon combustion, the K-Fuel product
produced approximately 20% lower NOx emissions and lower mercury emissions, as compared to untreated PRB coal and SO</font><sub><font size="2" color="black">2</font></sub><font size="2" color="black">emissions, well below the 1.2 pound per million Btu limit contained
in the second phase of the Clean Air Act, described more fully under &ldquo;Market for K-Fuel &ndash; Environmental Regulation.&rdquo;</font><font size="2">&nbsp; Additionally, based on the results of a February 1999 test burn, K-Fuel reduced NOx emissions (when
using PRB coal as the feedstock) as compared to typical eastern coals by levels approximating 25%.&nbsp; As higher quality feedstock generally results in higher quality outputs, the results of the 2000 and 1999 test burns may have been different if a feedstock other
than PRB coal were used.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; According to March 2003, March 2004 and February 2005 independent reports, K-Fuel provides an effective pre-combustion mercury
reduction technology.&nbsp; According to this independent research, a significant level of mercury is removed from coal during the K-Fuel production process.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Sasol-Lurgi Agreement</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Effective January 2, 2003, we signed an exclusive business development and intellectual property rights agreement with Sasol-Lurgi to
combine the K-Fuel technology with Sasol-Lurgi&rsquo;s technical services and equipment.&nbsp; We believe that Sasol-Lurgi&rsquo;s 70 plus years of experience in designing and building coal processing plants, including more than 450 process plants and equipment
installations since the first unit was constructed in 1927, add expertise to the commercial implementation of the K-Fuel process.&nbsp; Together with Sasol-Lurgi, we developed engineering specifications and Sasol-Lurgi assists in the supervision of the fabrication of
various component pieces of the equipment by third parties.&nbsp; With Sasol-Lurgi, we have modified the equipment and adjusted the temperature and pressure inside the vessels to meet the conditions necessary to produce</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 5</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">K-Fuel.&nbsp; Pursuant to the terms of the agreement, Sasol-Lurgi provides us with engineering, design and certain project management services and they agreed not to sell their coal beneficiation equipment utilizing our
technology to any other company in the world.&nbsp; We will be required to pay Sasol-Lurgi a one-time fee of approximately 11%, on purchases of their proprietary equipment design series and other fees.&nbsp; Once the fabrication and delivery of the equipment is
complete, there are no further licensing or other fees to be paid to Sasol-Lurgi.&nbsp; The agreement is in effect until such time that we no longer use the equipment for a period of three consecutive years.&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Landrica Development Company</font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On May&nbsp;21, 2004, we acquired all of the outstanding stock of Landrica from Wyodak Resources Development Corporation for cash of
$523,000 and assumption of a reclamation liability of $2.7 million.&nbsp; The assumption of the reclamation liability was secured with cash and is presented as restricted cash on the Consolidated Balance Sheets in Item 8 of this report.&nbsp; The results of Landrica
have been included in the Consolidated Financial Statements from the date of acquisition.&nbsp; Landrica owns a non-operating coalmine facility with assets that include land, buildings, coal handling equipment, a railroad loop and other pieces of equipment and
property.&nbsp; We are constructing our 750,000-ton plant on the land owned by Landrica.&nbsp; We believe that owning the land on which the demonstration facility and the 750,000-ton plant are located will provide efficiencies in operations and construction of the
plant.&nbsp; In addition, the other assets located on the parcel may be incorporated into the operation of the 750,000-ton plant or used for other income-related operations.&nbsp; See further discussion of the acquisition in Item 2 - Properties and Note 3 -
Acquisitions - Landrica Development Company in Item 8 of this report.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">750,000-ton Plant</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As mentioned above, we commenced the design and construction of the 750,000-ton plant in the Powder River Basin, near Gillette,
Wyoming.&nbsp; The fabrication of the vessels began in May 2003.&nbsp; We have obtained the long lead-time permits and construction of the plant commenced in November 2004.&nbsp; We believe that construction will be completed by the end of the summer with final
testing, commissioning and commercial production scheduled for the fourth quarter of 2005.&nbsp; Our schedule contemplates slower progress in the first few months of 2005 than in the spring and summer of 2005 due to the winter conditions in Wyoming.&nbsp; The plant
has a budget of approximately $52 million through final testing and commissioning.&nbsp; The increase in the budget from previously reported amounts of $48 million is the result of an increase in contingent reserves related to engineering costs, increase in the price
of steel and additional costs to expedite certain parts of the construction process.&nbsp; Through December&nbsp;31, 2004, we have spent approximately $20.1 million, including amounts reserved associated with a retirement obligation of $671,000 as required by the
Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, or DEQ.&nbsp; The costs to construct this facility are reflected in Plant Construction in Progress in our Consolidated Balance Sheets in Item 8 of this report.&nbsp; The 750,000-ton plant is being constructed with a
gas-fired boiler to produce the steam used in the K-Fuel process.&nbsp; A gas-fired boiler was selected primarily because the time to obtain permits is dramatically less than the time to obtain a permit for a coal-fired boiler.&nbsp; In future plants, we anticipate
using coal-fired boilers because the operating costs of a coal-fired boiler are substantially less than those of a gas-fired boiler, based upon current pricing of natural gas.&nbsp; We do not anticipate generating significant operating income from this plant in the
near future due to operating costs and the capacity of the plant.&nbsp; We are evaluating converting this gas-fired boiler to a coal-fired boiler, subject to appropriate permitting and regulatory approvals.&nbsp; While we believe our timing and cost estimates to
complete the construction and testing of the facility are reasonable, we can provide no assurance the plant will be completed in a timely manner or that it will be completed at or under the targeted costs. &nbsp; Further, we can provide no assurance that the plant
will operate as intended.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Other Development Activities</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are engaged in a number of other activities to develop the K-Fuel product and expand our business.&nbsp; We investigate other
potential sites for construction of future facilities including activities such as site evaluation, filing for certain permits and preliminary design specifications.&nbsp; As part of the site development process, we will evaluate the quality and quantity of available
feedstock sources and costs of transportation for both raw materials and finished products.&nbsp; We evaluate the status of these potential sites on a quarterly basis and if any site is no longer being considered or we anticipate that it will not be utilized in the
future, we write-off all associated costs in our Consolidated Statement of Operations in Item 8 of this report.&nbsp; We have written off costs related to sites no longer being considered in the amount of $1.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2004.&nbsp; There
were no such write-offs for the years ended December 31, 2003 and 2002.&nbsp; See further discussion in Note 5 &ndash; Plant Construction in progress in Item 8 of this report.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are also active in investigating alternatives to obtain additional capital to support the construction of more plants.&nbsp; These
alternatives primarily relate to selling licenses to other parties to construct plants and negotiating potential joint venture agreements.&nbsp; We have not yet entered into a joint venture or licensing agreements beyond the Cook Inlet Coal license agreement entered
into in December 2004.&nbsp; We anticipate seeking debt financing or project financing as we start to construct larger facilities.&nbsp; Additionally, as we develop our K-Fuel product, we expect to identify other opportunities to expand our business by</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 6</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">including other value-added services or other clean fuel alternatives.&nbsp; While we believe that we will obtain additional capital through one or more of the alternatives described, we can provide no assurance that any of
the alternatives will be available to us or be on terms acceptable to us.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On December 17, 2004, our wholly owned subsidiary, KFL, entered into a license agreement with Cook Inlet Coal, an affiliate of Kanturk
Partners LLC, under which KFL agreed to license to Cook Inlet Coal its proprietary coal processing technology for use at a coal processing plant to be operated by Cook Inlet Coal in Alaska.&nbsp; Pursuant to the agreement, KFL was paid a non-refundable technology
access fee of $7.5 million on December 24, 2004.&nbsp; The agreement also provides for additional payments upon plant commencement and plant completion and certain royalty payments once the plant is operational.&nbsp; The plant commencement and plant completion fees
vary in amount depending upon the capacity of the plant and the royalty payments are based on future profits and tax credits, if any, generated by the plant.&nbsp; The maximum permitted output of the plant is eight million short tons per annum.&nbsp; The plant is to
be situated near the Cook Inlet of Alaska, but another location may be authorized by KFL under certain circumstances.&nbsp; The term of the agreement is five years and shall automatically renew for consecutive five-year terms for the operational life of the plant,
provided that if Cook Inlet Coal has not begun construction within the first six years of the term, the license agreement will automatically terminate.&nbsp; In connection with the license agreement, K-Fuel and Cook Inlet Coal entered into a services agreement under
which KFL will provide services to Cook Inlet Coal related to the implementation of the technology granted to Cook Inlet Coal under the license agreement.&nbsp; While we anticipate that Cook Inlet Coal will build a plant, we can provide no assurance that they will
build a plant or the ultimate timing of any construction.&nbsp; As the permitting, design, construction and start-up period is estimated to be at least three years, we do not anticipate significant Cash Flow from Operations pursuant to this agreement in the near
future.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PATENTS AND TRADE SECRETS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Over the past 20 years, KFx has obtained multiple patents for different versions of the K-Fuel technology using a variety of methods to
apply heat and pressure to beneficiate high moisture coal feedstocks.&nbsp; We have patents or patent applications for the K-Fuel technology issued or pending in the United States and in over 40 foreign countries.&nbsp; As we continue to develop and make enhancements
to K-Fuel, we intend to continue to file for patent protection.&nbsp; The technological details that are most important to our process are those contained in our most recent patent application.&nbsp; As mentioned above, we have modified our technology to resolve
certain issues identified through the operation of the KFP Plant and through product testing at our demonstration plant by using a more uniform size of coal so that it will heat evenly, adjusting heat and pressure levels and utilizing the Sasol-Lurgi equipment.&nbsp;
As a result of these changes, we filed for a new patent in May 2004.&nbsp; Our case has been assigned to an examiner, but the examiner has not commenced an evaluation of our patent application.&nbsp; Generally, the patent approval process can take three or more years
to complete.&nbsp; While we believe that we will be granted a new patent, we can provide no assurance that the patent will be granted.&nbsp; Further, the patenting process can take several years and as a result we are uncertain as to the timing of the ultimate
granting or denial of our patent.&nbsp; If the patent is granted, it will expire in 2024.&nbsp; If this patent is not granted, we believe that earlier patents, expiring as late as 2021, will provide us adequate protection.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have undertaken a number of precautions, in addition to obtaining patents, to keep our technology proprietary.&nbsp; In order to
access or review the technology for any purpose, we require non-disclosure agreements or confidentiality provisions be incorporated into other agreements.&nbsp; All of our licensing agreements and the standard joint venture agreement we developed contain
confidentiality provisions.&nbsp; Such agreements or clauses are signed by significant vendors, such as Sasol-Lurgi, that access our technology in the course of providing a service to us.&nbsp; Additionally, all employees are required to sign similar confidentiality
agreements.&nbsp; Further, the employee agreements include provisions stating that any inventions relating to our technology as a result of employment are our property.&nbsp; These types of agreements create a legal obligation by the signor to use the information
only for the agreed upon purpose and not to disclose any of the information to third parties.&nbsp; We believe that we have adequately safeguarded our proprietary technology.&nbsp; However, we can make no assurance that others will not successfully replicate our
K-Fuel product in part or in total without infringing our patents.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">MARKET FOR K-FUEL</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The current market price of Eastern compliance coal compared with Western coal has enhanced the economics of producing K-Fuel.&nbsp;
Over the last couple of years, the pricing differential has increased dramatically.&nbsp; While we believe it is economical to produce K-Fuel when the pricing differential is at lower levels, this increase in the price differential has improved the economics of
selling K-Fuel.&nbsp; Additionally, the available supplies of Eastern compliance coal, primarily Central Appalachian coals, are declining.&nbsp; Based upon the reserve estimates by the U.S. Department of Energy, adjusted by KFx for recent production, there is
approximately 100 billion tons of compliance coal in the U.S. and it is declining at 1% per year.&nbsp; Further, we estimate that there is approximately 134 billion tons of coal in the U.S. that could serve as a feedstock for our process.&nbsp; As a result, the
potential market for Western coal and K-Fuel are expanding.&nbsp; Lastly in 2004, the legislation permitting tax credits for producers of synthetic fuels passed, further improving the potential economics of producing K-Fuel, assuming production produced from a K-Fuel
plant qualifies for the credits, which we believe we it does.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 7</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><a name="OLE_LINK1"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our primary market is domestic coal-fired EGUs and coal suppliers.&nbsp; We market K-Fuel to EGUs as a replacement
for certain current coal-fuel sources, which require high Btu, low sulfur coal.&nbsp; As reported by the U.S. Department of Energy, U.S. coal production in 2003 was nearly 1.1 billion tons, of which electric utilities consumed nearly 92%.&nbsp; Based upon preliminary
reports, coal production increased by approximately 4% during 2004.&nbsp; Coal-fired electricity generation currently accounts for 51% of the nation&rsquo;s total electricity supply.&nbsp; We believe that K-Fuel will provide a cleaner burning fuel source, which will
assist utilities in complying with environmental regulations, at prices that are competitive with compliance coal prices.&nbsp; For a number of years various regulations and other requirements have placed increasingly stringent standards on air emissions from the EGU
industry and others.&nbsp; In addition, there has been and will continue to be increasing pressure from regulation, legislation and competitive market forces to meet such air emission standards in more cost effective ways and to improve the overall efficiency of
electric power generation.&nbsp; Our process creates a market for lower-grade western coal, as the K-Fuel process uses this lower-grade coal as a feedstock to create enhanced higher-grade coal, which can then be sold to third parties.</font></a></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Environmental Regulation</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; There are numerous pieces of existing and proposed legislation and regulations that we believe will have profound impacts on fossil
fuel-fired, and specifically coal-fired, EGUs.&nbsp; According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or EPA, power generation in the U.S. is responsible for 67% of SO</font><sub><font size="2" color="black">2</font></sub><font size="2" color="black">emissions,
<sub></sub></font><font size="2" color="black">22% of NOx emissions and 37% of mercury emissions released into the environment by human activity.&nbsp; Regulation of these pollutants is important to improving environmental and public health.&nbsp; SO<sub>2</sub> and
NOx emissions contribute to acid rain and deposition, which adversely impact water and soil ecosystems.&nbsp; SO<sub>2</sub> and NOx pollution also contribute to the formation of particulate matter, or (PM), which reduces visibility and aggravates heart and lung
diseases (such as asthma).&nbsp; NOx contributes to ground-level ozone formation, also known as smog, and aggravates lung diseases.&nbsp; Mercury is a toxic pollutant that enters the human food chain when fish with high levels of methylmercury (a converted form of
mercury) are consumed.&nbsp; Women of childbearing age are the most sensitive population since consuming high levels of methylmercury can cause serious neurological development problems in developing fetuses.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following is a brief overview of legislation and regulatory drivers to provide further background of the environmental setting,
which affects the market for our K-Fuel product.&nbsp; While this is not a comprehensive overview of all legislation and regulations, it does provide information on some of the most applicable policies.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Clean Air Act and Acid Rain Program.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp; The Clean Air Act, or CAA, of 1970, and subsequent
amendments have been the primary drivers requiring reductions in emissions of SO</font><sub><font size="2" color="black">2</font></sub><font size="2" color="black">and NOx from sources such as EGUs, along with other air quality programs.&nbsp; A key component of the
CAA is the Acid Rain Program, also known as Title IV of the CAA, which was a significant part of the CAA Amendments of 1990.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Acid Rain Program seeks to cap SO<sub>2</sub> emissions from fossil-fuel-fired EGUs at half of 1980 emissions,
ultimately reaching a cap of 8.95 million tons by 2010.&nbsp; NOx emissions specifically from coal-fired EGUs are also reduced as part of the Acid Rain Program, to reach 6.1 million tons by 2002, 2 million tons below forecasted 2000 levels without the program.&nbsp;
The SO<sub>2</sub> emissions requirements were structured in two phases, the first phase began in 1995 and the second phase in 2000.&nbsp; NOx emissions were also reduced in two phases, 1996 and 2000.&nbsp;</font> <font size="2">The SO<sub>2</sub> program established
a cap and trade market-based program, to reduce emissions in a cost-effective and efficient manner.&nbsp; Cap and trade requires that facilities have enough allowances to cover total emissions, where one allowance is equal to one unit (usually a ton) of
emissions.&nbsp; Facilities must control emissions at or below the cap and can then bank excess allowances for future use or sell remaining allowances to facilities that do not meet the cap.&nbsp; The NOx program did not permit a cap and trade approach but instead
established emission rate limits according to boiler types for coal-fired units.&nbsp; As of 2003, the most recent year for which EPA has data, SO<sub>2</sub> emissions from fossil-fuel-fired EGUs were 10.6 million tons, a 38% reduction from 1980 levels and NOx
emissions from coal-fired EGUs were 4.2 million tons, nearly 4 million tons less than the emissions forecasted for 2000 and 37% below 1990 levels.&nbsp; In 2003, approximately 3,500 fossil fuel-fired units were subject to the SO<sub>2</sub> program and approximately
1,000 coal-fired units were subject to the NOx program.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Clear Skies Act.&nbsp;</font></b> <font size="2">The Clear Skies Initiative was announced in February 2002.&nbsp; In 2002 and 2003
the legislation, known as the Clear Skies Act, was introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives and U.S. Senate but did not pass through Congress.&nbsp; The Clear Skies Act seeks to decrease emissions of SO<sub>2</sub>, NOx and mercury from fossil fuel-fired
EGU&rsquo;s nationwide.&nbsp; <font color="black">The Clear Skies Act would impose a mandatory, nationwide cap on EGUs to achieve reductions in all three pollutants, as detailed below:</font></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Reducing SO</font><sub><font size="2">2</font></sub><font size="2">emissions by 73%, from an actual 11.2 million tons in 2000 to 4.5 million tons in 2010, 3.0 million tons in 2016, and 2.5 million tons by 2018</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Reducing NOx emissions by 67% from an actual 5.1 million tons in 2000 to 2.1 million tons in 2008 and 1.7 million tons by 2016; and</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 8</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Reducing mercury emission by 69% from an actual 48 tons in 2000 to 34 tons in 2010 and 15 tons in 2016 (this cap impacts only coal-fired power plants).</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Clear Skies Act sets a cap on emissions of SO<sub>2</sub>, NOx and mercury and allows power plants to control emissions through a
market-based cap and trade system, similar to the SO<sub>2</sub> cap and trade program established in the Acid Rain Program, described above.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Hearings in the Senate that were held in January and February failed to gain passage in the senate environment and Public Works
Committee on March 9, 2005.&nbsp; President Bush and the EPA support of the Clear Skies Act and hope it will still be able to gain Congressional approval this session.&nbsp; The legislation may be added to another piece of legislation, such as the energy
bill.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Clean Air Interstate Rule.&nbsp;</font></b> <font size="2">The Clean Air Interstate Rule, or CAIR, was proposed by the EPA in
January 2004.&nbsp; CAIR will cap SO<sub>2</sub> and NOx emissions in two phases, 2010 and 2015, and 2009 and 2015, respectively.&nbsp; Upon full implementation, SO<sub>2</sub> emissions will be reduced by 70% and NOx emissions by 61%.&nbsp; CAIR requires these
reductions from a region comprised of 28&nbsp; mostly eastern states and the District of Columbia compared to nationwide in the Clear Skies Act.&nbsp; Because emissions can be transported through air currents across state lines, impacting air quality in other
&ldquo;downwind&rdquo; states, the regulation seeks to cap emissions in these selected states to improve state and regional air quality.&nbsp; EPA anticipates states will achieve the emissions cap by reducing emissions from coal-fired power plants, though states can
choose to include other sources as well.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EPA was poised to finalize the CAIR rule by the end of 2004 but postponed the final rule in order to allow opportunity for Congress to
pass the Clear Skies Act in 2005.&nbsp; EPA prefers that Congress pass legislation reducing EGU emissions nationwide through federal legislation than through regulation.&nbsp; Due to the failure of the Clear Skies Act to gain the necessary votes in the Senate
Environment and Public Works Committee on March 9, the EPA finalized the CAIR rule on March 10.&nbsp; The emission reductions achieved by CAIR for the affected region includes:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Reducing SO</font><sub><font size="2">2</font></sub><font size="2">emissions by 73%, by 4.3 million tons by 2010 and by 5.4 million tons by 2015, achieving a cap of 2.5 million tons</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Reducing NOx emissions by 61%, by 1.7 million tons by 2009 and by 2 million tons by 2015, achieving a cap of 1.3 million tons</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; However if passed there is the possibility that the implementation could be delayed by potential litigation.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Clean Air Mercury Rule.</b>&nbsp; EPA also proposed the Clean Air Mercury Rule, or CAMR, in January 2004.&nbsp; Currently, mercury
emissions from coal-fired power plants are unregulated and CAMR could impose mandatory mercury emissions reduction on these sources for the first time.&nbsp; EPA&rsquo;s regulation was to be finalized by December 15, 2004 but finalization was extended to
March&nbsp;15, 2005 to allow time for additional analysis and public comment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EPA has proposed two possible ways to reduce mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants.&nbsp; Under the Maximum Achievable Control
Technology, or MACT, approach, each individual coal-fired unit would be required to cap mercury emissions.&nbsp; This would reduce mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants from 48 tons currently to approximately 34 tons by early 2008, a 30% reduction.&nbsp; An
alternative approach proposed by EPA allows coal-fired power plants to cap emissions in two phases and trade mercury allowances.&nbsp; The first cap in 2010 would be achieved as a co-benefit of facilities installing SO<sub>2</sub> and NOx emissions control equipment
to comply with the CAIR rule because these controls can help to reduce mercury.&nbsp; The second phase cap, in 2018,will reduce coal-fired power plant emissions to 15 tons.&nbsp; This approach realizes a total reduction in mercury emissions of nearly 70%.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We expect that the CAMR will be finalized on or before March 15, 2005.&nbsp; Statements by EPA officials as well as President Bush
indicate that it is likely that EPA will proceed with a cap and trade program for mercury emissions from coal-fired EGUs.&nbsp; Based upon such statements, we believe this approach will be the one finalized in the CAMR though there is the possibility that the MACT
approach could be finalized instead of a cap and trade program.&nbsp; The timeframe and emission caps, described above, as proposed by EPA may be the same or slightly modified in the final CAMR.&nbsp; We also anticipate that litigation against the final CAMR is
likely and could postpone implementation of a mercury standard for a significant period of time.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; American Jobs Creation Act Tax Credits.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp; In 2004, Congress passed tax credits for refined coal within
the American Jobs Creation Act.&nbsp; The tax credit is expected to be approximately $5.35 per ton, for each ton of refined coal produced during the qualifying period with annual adjustments in the credit amount for inflation.&nbsp; In order to qualify for the tax
credit, the refined</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 9</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">coal must realize a reduction of at least 20% in NOx emissions and at least 20% in either SO<sub>2</sub> or mercury emissions and have an increase in market value of at least 50%.&nbsp; Based upon testing we have performed to
date, we believe that K-Fuel meets the requirements of a refined coal and we believe our future plants that will produce K-Fuel will be eligible for the credit if they are operational by January 1, 2009.&nbsp; Generally, the eligible plants will earn the refined coal
credit for each ton produced over a ten-year period from the date the plant is placed in service.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Greenhouse Gas Emissions.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp; Currently, greenhouse gas emissions (such as carbon dioxide
(CO<sub>2</sub>) and others) are not regulated in the U. S.&nbsp; The Kyoto Protocol, the international treaty to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, was finalized in November 2004 and came into effect on February 16, 2005 without United States participation.&nbsp;
Several members of Congress have proposed legislation to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through various methods in the U. S. but such efforts have not been successful.&nbsp; It is likely that legislation will be introduced in the 2005 session seeking to reduce
greenhouse gas emissions, either as a bill focusing solely on greenhouse gases or as a bill that also encompasses reductions in SO<sub>2</sub>, NOx and mercury.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; NOx SIP Call.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp; NOx emissions emitted from power plants, vehicles, and other sources mix with Volatile
Organic Compounds (VOCs, also emitted from these sources) in the presence of heat and light to form ground-level ozone, also known as smog.&nbsp; Ozone formation is most prevalent and harmful to breath for sensitive populations (including people with respiratory
disease, young children and people that are active outside) during the summer months.&nbsp; The NOx State Implementation Plan, or SIP, Call is EPA&rsquo;s regulation requiring 21 eastern states and the District of Columbia to reduce summertime ozone formation by
controlling NOx emissions from May through September.&nbsp; Eight states and D.C. began reductions in 2003 with 11 more states taking part in 2004.&nbsp; Two additional states will begin participating in 2007.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ozone and Fine Particulate Matter National Ambient Air Quality Standards.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp; Ozone and particulate
matter, or PM, pollution have significant adverse impacts on human health.&nbsp; Fine particulate matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>, approximately 1/30<sup>th</sup> the size of a human hair) is especially harmful since it can be breathed deep into the lungs.&nbsp; As a
result, EPA has established National Ambient Air Quality Standards, or NAAQS, for ozone and PM<sub>2.5</sub> pollution levels that each county must not exceed.&nbsp; In 2004, EPA announced that 224 counties in the U.S. are in &ldquo;non-attainment&rdquo; of the
PM<sub>2.5</sub> NAAQS and 474 counties are in &ldquo;non-attainment&rdquo; of the ozone NAAQS.&nbsp; The counties in these states must now implement policies that will reduce emissions of NOx and SO<sub>2</sub>, which contribute to the formation of ozone and
PM<sub>2.5</sub>.&nbsp; The timeline for counties to achieve these reductions varies depending on the severity of the non-attainment.&nbsp; Areas will have until 2010 or 2015 to reach attainment of the PM<sub>2.5</sub> NAAQS and until 2007 through 2021 to attain the
ozone NAAQS.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Other Domestic and International Markets</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As mentioned above, electric utility plants consume approximately 92% of the total coal produced in the U.S.&nbsp; In addition to
EGU&rsquo;s we also plan to market our products to those remaining entities that burn coal in their boilers or processes, primarily in the manufacturing industry.&nbsp; These companies are also subject to environmental regulations and could benefit from
K-Fuel.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The international coal-fired power generation industry is approximately four times the size of the U.S. coal-fired power generation
industry.&nbsp; Our objective is to concentrate on international markets where there is either a significant need for more energy efficient and environmentally responsible fuel products to comply with the Kyoto Protocol or similar regulations in effect throughout the
world, or where abundant lower grade coal reserves can be utilized in conjunction with the K-Fuel technology to develop a value-added export product.&nbsp; The principal benefit of the K-Fuel technology in foreign markets is that lower-grade, indigenous coal reserves
can be upgraded to provide a more cost effective and less environmentally damaging fuel source for power producers, manufacturers and households, either for internal markets or for export.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Acceptance of our Product</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We believe that our product will be accepted by the market place, as it is a fuel source, which is also a cost-effective alternative to
the increasing costs of complying with environmental regulation.&nbsp; Coal-fired EGU&rsquo;s have a number of options available to them to comply with regulations.&nbsp; These include conversions to utilize alternative fuel sources (e.g. natural gas), installation
of pollution control equipment (e.g. scrubbers) and /or injection of additives to reduce emissions (e.g. limestone injection).&nbsp; These options can require significant capital or operating expenditures.&nbsp; Due to the increased scrutiny of costs by the public
and public utility commissions, we believe K-Fuel provides a cost-effective alternative for compliance.&nbsp; However, we can provide no assurance that our product will be accepted by the market place.&nbsp; See Competition below for further discussion of
alternatives to our product.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 10</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lastly, environmental regulations that created the cap and trade market-based programs, described above, could also create a market for
our K-Fuel product.&nbsp; As K-Fuel is a clean-burning fuel source, it could be used to reduce emissions.&nbsp; This could permit utilities to generate allowances for use or sale of any excess allowances to non-compliant organizations.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Competition</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; K-Fuel is an upgraded coal characterized by low-moisture, high-Btu content, and low sulfur, NOx, dust and mercury emissions.&nbsp; As
such, the known direct competitors for K-Fuel include other coal upgrading processes, other high Btu coal, low sulfur coal and so-called clean coal technology companies that produce equipment to reduce the emissions from the combustion of coal.&nbsp; The indirect
competition to K-Fuel includes electrical generation from natural gas, nuclear fuel, oil, wind, bio-fuels, and other renewable energy sources.&nbsp; Over the past two years, pricing trends for a number of these alternatives have enhanced the competitive position of
K-Fuel.&nbsp; While current trends in prices for these competing energy sources improve the viability of our K-Fuel product, there can be no assurance these trends will continue.&nbsp; Many of these companies may have greater financial, technical, and operational
resources than we do.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are aware that other companies either have performed in the past, or are currently performing development work on upgrading
lower-grade coal.&nbsp; Some of these companies may have greater financial, technical, and operational resources than we do.&nbsp; We are unaware of any past, current, or projected coal upgrading technology for lower-grade coal that produces fuel of comparable
quality, emissions reductions, and marketability with the commercial potential of K-Fuel.&nbsp; We are also aware that other companies produce coal of similar energy content, moisture content, and sulfur content to that of K-Fuel.&nbsp; Many of these companies may
have greater financial, technical, and operational resources than we do.&nbsp; We are not aware of companies that produce and market such coal with the low NOx and mercury emissions and low dust of K-Fuel.&nbsp; We also believe that K-Fuel will have certain
production, logistical, transportation, and distribution advantages over known competitors in particular markets.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Potential customers could choose to install pollution equipment instead of using K-Fuel and /or injection of additives to reduce
emissions.&nbsp; This equipment includes low-NOx burners, over-fire air systems, selective catalytic reduction systems, sulfur scrubbers, fabric filters, electrostatic precipitators, mercury control technology, or other equipment.&nbsp; In contrast to K-Fuel, most of
these technologies require a significant investment of funds by the customer and impose a parasitic load on the plant, thereby reducing the salable electricity produced from the effected unit.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><a name="OLE_LINK2"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">REGULATIONS THAT AFFECT THE CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION OF OUR PLANTS</font></b></a></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As a general matter, we are subject to a number of state and federal regulations that (i) seek to limit the amounts of certain
emissions into the environment; (ii) regulate the disposal of certain potentially hazardous materials; and (iii) impose certain employee safety requirements upon us.&nbsp; While the coal mining and electric power generation industries are subject to significant
regulation, we believe that our exposure to such regulation is more limited because of the current nature of our operations.&nbsp; However, as we expand our operations we may become subject to more regulation.&nbsp; For example, if we build additional plants we may
install coal-fired boilers, which are subject to more permitting requirements and more environmental regulation than gas-fired boilers.&nbsp; Further, if we chose to mine coal from the pit obtained in the Landrica acquisition, we or a contract miner would be subject
to all of the regulations associated with coal mining.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In the United States, the K-Fuel product is not expected to be subject to unusual levels of local, state or federal regulation with
respect to its transportation and distribution.&nbsp; However, any future U. S. production plants will require numerous permits, approvals and certificates from appropriate federal, state and local governmental agencies before construction of each facility can begin
and will be required to comply with applicable environmental laws and regulations (including obtaining operating permits) once facilities begin production.&nbsp; The most significant types of permits that are typically required for commercial production facilities
include an operating and construction permit under the CAA, a wastewater discharge permit under the Clean Water Act, and a treatment, storage and disposal permit under the Resource Conservation Act.&nbsp; Some of the federal programs have been delegated to the states
and, as a result, facilities may be required to secure state permits.&nbsp; Finally, the construction of new facilities may require review under the National Environmental Policy Act, or NEPA, or a state equivalent, which requires analysis of environmental
impacts.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Future international K-Fuel production plants will also be subject to various permitting and operational regulations specific to each
country.&nbsp; Generally, environmental permitting and operating regulations in countries outside the U.S. that we are currently pursuing for international development are not as stringent as those that are within the U.S.&nbsp; Nevertheless, international
initiatives, such as the Kyoto Protocol, are expected to create increasing pressures on the electric power generation industry on a world-wide basis to reduce emissions of various pollutants, which management expects will create additional demand for our products and
services.</font></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 11</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

The most significant of these transactions are summarized as follows:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>
