<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.</font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-5</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>
</div>

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><br clear="all" />
</font>

<div>
<p align="center"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">KFX INC.<br />
<a name="fin14120_24"></a>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br />
For the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002</font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Unless the context requires otherwise, the terms &ldquo;KFx,&rdquo; &ldquo;we,&rdquo; &ldquo;our,&rdquo; and &ldquo;us&rdquo; refer to
KFx Inc. and its subsidiaries.&nbsp; All references to K-Fuel, K-Fuel</font><sup><font size="2" color="black">&trade;</font></sup><font size="2" color="black">and K-Fuel Plus</font><sup><font size="2" color="black">&trade;</font></sup><font size="2" color=
"black">refer to our patented process and technology.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 1.&nbsp;NATURE OF OPERATIONS</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; KFx is a &ldquo;clean coal &rdquo; company with a patented process and technology, which we refer to as K-Fuel technology, that uses
heat and pressure to physically and chemically transform coal with a lower heat value, as measured by British Thermal Units into coal with a higher heat value, while at the same time removing significant amounts of certain impurities.&nbsp; Our technology adds value
for coal producers and the electric power generation industry by significantly improving the quality of lower-grade coal and facilitating its compliance with certain air emission standards.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We incorporated under the laws of the state of Delaware in 1988.&nbsp; Our financial statements include all of our wholly owned
subsidiaries, including Landrica Development Company, which was acquired in May 2004.&nbsp; See further discussion of the Landrica acquisition in Note 3 - Acquisitions - Landrica Development Company.&nbsp; During 2003, as a part of an exchange transaction with
Kennecott Energy Company, we transferred our ownership of Pegasus Technologies, Inc., to Kennecott for its remaining interest in K-Fuel LLC, or KFL, that we did not own.&nbsp; As a result of this exchange, we accounted for Pegasus as a discontinued operation and have
accordingly removed its effects from our results of operations for 2003 and 2002.&nbsp; Additionally, KFL is now a wholly owned subsidiary.&nbsp; See further discussion in Note 3 &ndash; Acquisitions &ndash; Investment in K-Fuel LLC and Note 13 &ndash; Discontinued
Pegasus Operations.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our operations have required and will continue to require investment for research and development of our K-Fuel product, construction
of our 750,000-tons per year K-Fuel plant near Gillette, Wyoming, or 750,000-ton plant, and construction of other large-scale commercial plants.&nbsp; We expect to continue to incur operating losses for at least the next several years as we complete the construction
of our 750,000-ton plant and undertake the design, construction and operation of other large-scale commercial plants.&nbsp; Further, we do not expect to derive a significant amount of cash from operations until at least some plants are fully operational.&nbsp;
Historically, we have satisfied our cash requirements primarily through the sale of equity securities.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 2.&nbsp;SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES</font></b></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Consolidation Policy</b></font></i><b><font size="2">.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;The accompanying
consolidated financial statements include the accounts of KFx and our wholly owned subsidiaries.&nbsp; All intercompany amounts and transactions have been eliminated.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On May&nbsp;21, 2004, we acquired all of the outstanding stock of Landrica from Wyodak Resources Development
Corporation for cash of $523,000 and assumption of a reclamation liability of $2.7 million.&nbsp; The results of Landrica have been included in the consolidated financial statements from the date of acquisition.&nbsp; See Note 3 - Acquisitions - Landrica Development
Company for further discussion.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In November 2003, we completed an exchange transaction whereby we disposed of our interest in Pegasus and acquired the
remaining interest in KFL.&nbsp; A detailed description of the equity exchange transaction involving Pegasus and KFL is provided in Note 13 - Discontinued Pegasus Operations and Note 3 &ndash; Acquisitions &ndash; Investment in K-Fuel LLC.&nbsp; Prior to
November&nbsp;26, 2003, the operations of KFL were accounted for as an equity investment since our 49% partner, Kennecott, had certain participative rights.&nbsp; Beginning November 26, 2003, the operations of KFL are consolidated.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Estimates.</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">The preparation of financial statements in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, or GAAP, requires us to make estimates, assumptions and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities as of the date
of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the periods presented.&nbsp; We believe that the significant estimates, assumptions and judgments when accounting for items and matters such as depreciation, amortization, asset
valuations, allowance for bad debts, taxes, internal labor capitalization rates, recoverability of assets, impairments, customer retention, reserves and other provisions are reasonable, based upon information available at the time they are made.&nbsp; Actual results
could differ from these estimates, making it possible that a change in these estimates could occur in the near term.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Reclassifications.</b></font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain prior year balances have been reclassified to
conform to the current year presentation.</font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Cash and cash equivalents</b></font></i><b><font size="2">.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash and cash
equivalents consist of highly liquid investments that consist primarily of taxable, short-term money market instruments and overnight deposits with insignificant interest rate risk and original maturities of</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-6</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">three months or less at the time of purchase.&nbsp; We utilize and invest with financial institutions that are sound and of high credit quality.&nbsp; Our investments are in low-risk instruments and we limit our
credit exposure in any one institution or type of investment instrument based upon criteria including credit worthiness.</font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Restricted cash.</b></font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;We have restricted cash set aside in a joint custody
account for the benefit of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, or DEQ.&nbsp; This cash serves as collateral pledged toward our reclamation liability assessed by the DEQ, primarily on the non-operating mine assets owned by Landrica.&nbsp; The obligation
has increased due to development activities undertaken at the site, primarily the construction of our 750,000-ton plant.&nbsp; Until the asset retirement obligation is relieved, this cash will remain restricted.&nbsp; Furthermore, if and when the asset retirement
obligation assessment increases or decreases, we may be required to pledge additional cash collateral or may be allowed to un-restrict this cash as the case may be.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Plant construction in progress and property, plant and equipment</b></font></i></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Plant construction in progress.&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">All costs that are directly related to the
engineering, design, purchase or fabrication of K-Fuel<font color="black">plant equipment and which are expected to be used in a commercial K-Fuel plant project are capitalized.&nbsp; All costs that are directly related to/or allocable to developing a specific K-Fuel
plant site for a commercial plant project are capitalized and separately identified as belonging to that site.&nbsp; Employee-related costs directly related to construction are also capitalized during the construction phase.&nbsp; If it is determined the site will
not generate future cash flows or is expected to generate less cash flow than originally expected the capitalized costs are evaluated for impairment.&nbsp; Any cost that is not directly related to specific equipment or development of a specific site is
expensed.&nbsp; We begin depreciation on plant assets once the assets are placed into service.&nbsp; Accordingly, no depreciation has been recognized on the 750,000-ton plant assets to date.</font></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Other property, plant, and equipment.</font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;Other property, plant, and equipment
consists of buildings, furniture and fixtures, computers, vehicles, leasehold improvements, coal handling, water treatment, injection wells, land and asset retirement costs.&nbsp; Expenditures that extend the useful lives of assets are capitalized.&nbsp; Repairs and
maintenance that do not extend the useful lives of the assets are expensed as incurred.&nbsp; Depreciation expense is computed using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives for other property and equipment.</font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Asset retirement cost and obligation.</b></font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2001, the Financial
Accounting Standards Board, or FASB, issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standard, or SFAS, No. 143, &ldquo;Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations&rdquo; (or SFAS 143).&nbsp; SFAS 143 provides guidance for accounting and disclosure requirements for
retirement obligations associated with long-lived assets.&nbsp; SFAS 143 requires that the fair value of the retirement obligation be recorded as a liability with an equivalent amount added to the asset cost and depreciated over an appropriate period.&nbsp; The
liability is then accreted over time by applying an interest method of allocation to the liability.&nbsp; We expect to begin accreting in 2005.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As part of our acquisition of Landrica, we agreed to assume the reclamation liability associated with the non-operating
coal mine assets owned by Landrica.&nbsp; The fair value of this liability was determined by the DEQ.&nbsp; This reclamation liability was recorded at its fair value as determined by the DEQ on the date of acquisition and an equivalent amount was added to the asset
cost.&nbsp; Beginning in 2005, we will accrete the liability related to the acquisition.&nbsp; Other adjustments to the liability will be made if, and when, the DEQ changes its assessment.&nbsp; The asset is amortized over the useful life of the underlying
assets.&nbsp; In November 2004, we filed various permits and broke ground on the 750,000-ton plant, and as a result, the DEQ assessed a reclamation liability related to the 750,000-ton plant and other anticipated construction on the site.&nbsp; This additional layer
of reclamation liability is included in Plant Under Construction in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Patents</b></font></i><b><font size="2">.</font></b><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;All costs incurred to the point when
a patent application is to be filed are expensed as incurred; costs, generally legal costs, thereafter are capitalized.&nbsp; The costs of defending and maintaining patents are expensed as incurred.&nbsp; Patents are amortized over the expected useful lives of the
patents, which is generally 17 to 20 years for domestic patents and 5 to 20 years for foreign patents.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Long-lived assets.</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">We evaluate long-lived assets based on estimated future
undiscounted net cash flows whenever significant events or changes in circumstances occur that indicate the carrying amount may not be recoverable.&nbsp; If that evaluation indicates that impairment has occurred, a charge is recognized to the extent the carrying
amount exceeds the discounted cash flows or fair values of the asset, whichever is more readily determinable.&nbsp; In addition, we capitalized certain costs related to investigating potential sites for future facilities.&nbsp; We evaluate the status of these
potential sites on a quarterly basis and if any site has been abandoned or we anticipate that it will be abandoned, we write-off all associated costs.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As of December 31, 2002, management retained an independent appraisal firm to perform an analysis under SFAS No. 142,
&ldquo;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&rdquo; of the goodwill that resulted from our acquisitions of Pegasus and the Power Optimization Segment of Pavilion Technologies, Inc.&nbsp; The goodwill impairment analysis was completed by comparing the fair value of the
Pegasus reporting unit to its book value, including goodwill, and the goodwill was deemed to not be impaired.&nbsp; The</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-7</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">goodwill related to the acquisition of Pegasus was disposed of as of December 31, 2003 as part of the exchange transaction more fully described in Note 13 &ndash; Discontinued Pegasus Operations.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Deferred financing costs.</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">KFx capitalized issuance costs related to the
convertible debentures.&nbsp; These costs were amortized over the life of the debentures using the straight-line method, the results of which were not materially different than using the effective interest method.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003 all debt issuance costs
had been amortized.&nbsp; See Note 9 &ndash; Convertible Debentures for further discussion of the debentures.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Fair value of financial instruments.</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">The carrying amount of cash and cash
equivalents, accounts payable, accrued liabilities and the current portion of long-term obligations in the consolidated financial statements approximate fair value because of the short-term nature of the instruments.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Revenue.</b></font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;We recognize revenue from K-Fuel licenses and royalties when there
is persuasive evidence of an arrangement, generally when an agreement has been signed, all significant obligations have been satisfied, the fee is fixed or determinable and collection is reasonably assured.&nbsp; Any up-front fees received related to licenses granted
are deferred and recognized over the provision of specific deliverables as defined in the agreement.&nbsp; As our history related to customer relationships is limited, we may be required to change the estimated period over which we amortize our revenue as more
information becomes available.&nbsp; Arrangements that include multiple deliverables are evaluated to determine whether the elements are separable based on objective evidence.&nbsp; If the elements are deemed separable, total consideration is allocated to each
element and the revenue associated with each element is recognized as earned.&nbsp; If the elements are not deemed separable, total consideration is deferred and recognized ratably over the longer of the contractual period or the expected customer relationship
period.&nbsp; KFx recognizes revenue related to research and development contracts as the services are performed under third party contracts.&nbsp; This revenue is comprised of multiple contracts and these contracts are entered into intermittently.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Pegasus software license and services revenue.</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">Prior to the disposition of
Pegasus, more fully discussed in Note 13 &ndash; Discontinued Pegasus Operations, we recognized revenue in the operations of Pegasus in accordance with the provisions of Statement of Position, or SOP, 97-2, &ldquo;Software Revenue Recognition&rdquo; as amended by SOP
98-9, &ldquo;Modification of Statement of Position 97-2, <i>Software Revenue Recognition</i>, with Respect to Certain Transactions.&rdquo;&nbsp; Pegasus derived revenues from license fees, for their NeuSIGHT</font><sup><font size="2" color=
"black">&reg;</font></sup><font size="2">and Perfecter</font><sup><font size="2" color="black">&reg;</font></sup><font size="2">software, and services, including installation, implementation, maintenance and training, under the terms of both fixed-price and
time-and-materials contracts.&nbsp; Revenues were not recognized until persuasive evidence of an arrangement existed, either by way of a signed contract or signed purchase order, collectibility was reasonably assured, delivery had occurred or services had been
rendered and the price was fixed or determinable.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where services were essential to the functionality of the delivered software, the license fee and services revenue was
generally recognized using the percentage-of-completion method of accounting, as prescribed by SOP 81-1 &ldquo;Accounting for Performance of Construction-Type and Certain Production-Type Contracts&rdquo;.&nbsp; The percentage of completion for each contract was
determined based on the ratio of direct labor hours incurred to total estimated direct labor hours required to complete the contract.&nbsp; The Company may have periodically encountered changes in costs, estimated costs and other factors that may have led to a change
in the original estimated profitability of a fixed-price contract.&nbsp; In such circumstances, adjustments to cost and profitability estimates were made in the periods in which the underlying factors requiring such revisions became known.&nbsp; If such revisions
indicated a loss on a contract, the entire loss was recorded at such time.&nbsp; Amounts billed in advance of services being performed were recorded as deferred revenue.&nbsp; Unbilled work-in-progress represents revenue earned but not yet billable under the terms of
fixed price contracts and all such amounts were expected to be billed in accordance with performance milestones specified in the contract and collected within twelve months.&nbsp; Deferred job costs represent up-front hardware costs incurred that would be amortized
to expense over the term of related revenue recognition.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Services revenue provided under fixed-price contracts was generally recognized using the percentage-of-completion method
of accounting described above.&nbsp; Revenue from other services provided pursuant to time-and-materials contracts was recognized as the services were performed.&nbsp; Annual maintenance revenue was recorded as deferred revenue and recognized ratably over the service
period, which was generally twelve months.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Research and Development.</b></font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs incurred to advance, test, or otherwise
modify our proprietary technology or develop new technologies are considered research and development costs until such time as the modification or new technology is ready for protection through patent and are expensed when incurred.&nbsp; These costs are primarily
comprised of costs associated with the operation of our laboratory and pilot plants and operations of one of our subsidiaries, including salaries and wages, supplies, repair and maintenance, general office expenses and professional fees.&nbsp; Once patents are
applied for, certain of these costs are capitalized as a cost of obtaining the patents.&nbsp; Further as construction of a commercial property has commenced, certain of these costs are capitalized as a part of the plant.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-8</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Loss from discontinued operations.</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">Prior to its disposal in November 2003,
Pegasus was reported and accounted for as an operating segment.&nbsp; For purposes of the Consolidated Statement of Operations, the loss from operating Pegasus has been aggregated into a single line called &ldquo;Loss from discontinued operations.&rdquo;&nbsp; We
made the determination to account for the disposal of these operations as discontinued in accordance with SFAS No. 144, &ldquo;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&rdquo; because (a) it has been determined that the operations and cash flows
of this asset were eliminated from our on-going operations and (b) we do not expect to have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of Pegasus in the future.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b>Stock-based compensation.</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></i> <font size="2">We periodically grant qualified and
non-qualified stock options to certain executive officers and other key employees, non-employee directors and certain consultants under five stock option plans, as well as outside the plans.&nbsp; Stock options granted to employees and directors are accounted for in
accordance with Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 25, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&rdquo; (&ldquo;APB 25&rdquo;) and related interpretations, which generally provide that no compensation expense is recorded in connection with the granting of
stock options if the options are granted at prices at least equal to the fair value of the common stock at date of grant.&nbsp; Stock options and other equity instruments granted to non-employees are accounted for in accordance with SFAS No. 123, &ldquo;Accounting
for Stock-Based Compensation&rdquo; and Emerging Issues Task Force Abstract No. 96-18, &ldquo;Accounting for Equity Instruments That are Issued to Other Than Employees for Acquiring or in Conjunction with Selling, Goods or Services&rdquo; (&ldquo;EITF
96-18&rdquo;).&nbsp; Accordingly, stock options granted to non-employees are measured using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model and are expensed over the expected service period.&nbsp; See Note 11 &ndash; Stock Option Plans for further discussion of our stock option
plans.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Had compensation expense for our stock options granted to employees been recognized based on the fair value over the
vesting period for the awards consistent with the method of SFAS 123, our pro forma net loss and net loss per share would have been reported as follows:</font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The pro forma amounts reflected above may not be representative of the effects on our reported net income or loss in future years
because the number of future shares to be issued is not known and assumptions used to determine fair value vary significantly.&nbsp; See Note 11 &ndash; Stock Option Plans for further discussion of our plans.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Income taxes.</font></i></b> <font size="2">&nbsp; Income tax expense is the amount of income taxes expected to be
payable for the current year.&nbsp; A deferred tax asset or liability is computed for both the expected future impact of differences between the financial statement and tax basis of assets and liabilities and for the expected future tax benefit to be derived from tax
loss and tax credit carryforwards.&nbsp; Valuation allowances are established when necessary to reduce deferred tax assets to the amount expected to be realized, based upon an assessment of both negative and positive evidence, in future tax returns.&nbsp; Tax rate
changes are reflected in our results of operations in the period such changes are enacted.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-9</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p align="left"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Net loss per common share.&nbsp;</font></i></b> <font size="2">Basic net loss per common share is based on the
weighted-average number of common shares actually outstanding during each respective year.&nbsp; The calculation of diluted net earnings per common share adds the weighted-average number of potential common shares outstanding to the weighted-average common shares
actually outstanding, except for instances in which there is a net loss.&nbsp; Our incremental potential common shares outstanding at December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 are 19.3 million, 23.4 million and 26.5 million, respectively and are comprised of stock options
outstanding as described in Note 11 &ndash; Stock Option Plans and warrants to purchase our common stock as described in Note 12 - Warrants.&nbsp; All potential common shares outstanding have been excluded from diluted net loss per common share because the impact of
such inclusion on a net loss would be anti-dilutive.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Comprehensive income.&nbsp;</font></i></b> <font size="2">SFAS No. 130, &ldquo;Reporting Comprehensive Income&rdquo;
establishes standards for reporting comprehensive income and its components in financial statements.&nbsp; Comprehensive income includes all changes in equity during a period from non-owner sources.&nbsp; During each of the three years ended December 31, 2004, we had
no transactions that were required to be reported as adjustments to determine comprehensive income.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Segments.</font></i></b><b><font size="2">&nbsp;</font></b> <font size="2">Currently, we operate our business in one
segment.&nbsp; This segment primarily contains our corporate operations; our research and development activities; and the construction of our 750,000-ton plant.&nbsp; The majority of the assets associated with this segment are those related to our patents, the
demonstration facility and the construction costs and equipment of the 750,000-ton plant.&nbsp; We currently manage our business in one segment as our operations are focused on developing the technology and the commercial viability of our product.&nbsp; As a result,
our results of operations are evaluated and allocations of capital resources are based upon the operations of one segment.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Recent Accounting Pronouncements.</font></i></b></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December&nbsp;2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board, or FASB, issued Statement of Financial Accounting
Standard, or SFAS, No.&nbsp;123R, &ldquo;Share-Based Payment,&rdquo; or SFAS 123R.&nbsp; SFAS 123R requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in financial statements based on the fair value of the equity or liability
instruments issued.&nbsp; We will be required to apply SFAS 123R as of the interim reporting period beginning July&nbsp;1, 2005.&nbsp; SFAS 123R covers a wide range of share-based compensation arrangements including share options, restricted share plans,
performance-based awards, share appreciation rights, and employee share purchase plans.&nbsp; We are still evaluating the impacts of adopting SFAS 123R upon our financial position and results of operations.&nbsp; Based upon preliminary evaluations, we anticipate that
adoption will result in significant non-cash expense due to the number of unvested stock options outstanding.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;153, &ldquo;Exchanges of Non-monetary Assets,&rdquo; or SFAS 153,
which is effective for starting July&nbsp;1, 2005.&nbsp; Under SFAS 153, we will measure assets exchanged at fair value, as long as the transaction has commercial substance and the fair value of the assets exchanged is determinable within reasonable limits.&nbsp; A
non-monetary exchange has commercial substance if the future cash flows of the entity are expected to change significantly as a result of the exchange.&nbsp; The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;153 is not anticipated to have a material effect on our financial position or
results of operations.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 3&nbsp;ACQUISITIONS</font></b></p>

<p align="left"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p align="left"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Landrica Development Company</font></b></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On May&nbsp;21, 2004, we acquired all of the outstanding stock of Landrica from Wyodak Development Corporation, or Wyodak
for cash of $523,000 and assumption of a reclamation liability of $2.7 million.&nbsp; The results of Landrica have been included in the consolidated financial statements from the date of acquisition.&nbsp; Landrica owns a non-operating coalmine and related assets
that include land, buildings, coal handling equipment, a railroad loop and other pieces of equipment and property.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-10</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

information becomes available.&nbsp; Following is a summary of the estimated fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the date of the acquisition (dollars in thousands):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Since Landrica was not operating the mine during 2004, 2003 or 2002 the operating results, including revenue and net
income are insignificant.&nbsp; Therefore, pro-forma results as if the acquisition had occurred at the beginning of the respective period are not presented.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As part of the purchase agreement we agreed to assume the reclamation liability associated with the non-operating coal
mine assets owned by Landrica.&nbsp; The fair value of this liability is determined from time-to-time by the DEQ.&nbsp; This reclamation liability was recorded at its fair value as determined by the DEQ on the date of acquisition and an equivalent amount was added to
the asset cost.&nbsp; The assumption of the reclamation liability was secured with cash and is presented as restricted cash in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Investment In K-Fuel, LLC</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In November 2003, KFx acquired all interests in KFL not previously owned pursuant to the exchange agreement more fully disclosed in
Note 13 - Discontinued Pegasus Operations.&nbsp; Prior to the date of the transaction, KFX owned 51% and Kennecott owned 49% of the interests.&nbsp; The assets acquired in this transaction were insignificant.&nbsp; As a result of this transaction, KFL is now
consolidated within our financial statements.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; KFL incurred research and development costs totaling approximately $92,000 and $54,000 in 2003 and 2002, respectively.&nbsp; We
contributed approximately $66,000 to KFL during 2003.&nbsp; We recognized losses of $209,000 and $1,000 in 2003 and 2002, respectively for our share of the expenses of KFL.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<h5><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 4.&nbsp;NOTE RECEIVABLE</font></b></h5>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On July 25, 2001, Cinergy Corporation (&ldquo;Cinergy&rdquo;) advanced $3.5 million, bearing interest at 7% per annum, payable monthly,
to Pegasus related to an existing contract.&nbsp; The advance could be repaid at the election of Cinergy by (1) applying future Pegasus invoices against the advance; (2) converting the balance of the advance into either KFx or Pegasus common stock; or (3) requiring
repayment of the advance under certain circumstances.&nbsp; As consideration for the advance, Cinergy received warrants to purchase 200,000 shares of KFx common stock, with beneficial re-pricing rights, contingent on us repaying our convertible debentures.&nbsp; See
Note 9 &ndash; Convertible Debentures for a discussion of such debentures.&nbsp; In connection with the advance, we amortized $66,000 and $42,000 for the years ended December 31, 2003 and 2002 related to deferred financing costs.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On September 11, 2003, Cinergy elected to convert its advance to Pegasus into common stock of KFx.&nbsp; The advance balance was $2.4
million on September 11, 2003, and was converted into 871,000 shares of KFx stock at a price of $2.75 per share, in accordance with the terms of the agreement.&nbsp; At conversion of this note receivable, Pegasus became indebted to KFx for the remainder of the
balance outstanding.&nbsp; Payments on the note are due pursuant to an assignment of certain cash proceeds due to Pegasus from Cinergy.&nbsp; We have certain rights to collect payments under this note from Pegasus and to demand payment upon certain events of
default.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In connection with our disposal of Pegasus, we incurred $500,000 in costs related to the acceleration of royalty obligations owed by
Pegsus to Pavilion Technologies, Inc., or Pavilion, due to a change in control.&nbsp; Half of these costs, or $250,000, were added to this note receivable due from Pegasus.&nbsp; See further discussion of our disposal of Pegasus and costs we incurred in Note
13</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-11</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&ndash; Discontinued Pegasus Operations.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2004 and 2003 the total balance due on this note was $2.1 and $2.5 million, respectively, and the current amount receivable was $334,000 and&nbsp; $992,000,
respectively.&nbsp; The proceeds from Cinergy received by Pegasus have been slower than anticipated.&nbsp; Pegasus continues to make its scheduled monthly interest payments, however, their financial condition is deteriorating.&nbsp; We regularly evaluate the
collectibility of this receivable.&nbsp; In the event sufficient evidence develops that indicates that Pegasus will not be able to meet some or all of its obligation, we will reserve for the appropriate amount of the receivable.&nbsp; The portion of the note
allocated to current represents our best estimate of the amount we anticipate collecting in the next year.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Depreciation expense was $268,000, $111,000 and $86,000 in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.&nbsp; The
K-Fuel</font><sup><font size="2" color="black"></font></sup><font size="2">demonstration facility was fully depreciated.&nbsp; The facility continues to be a significant source of testing and demonstration for our potential customers, as a result, we have presented
its original cost basis and accumulated depreciation for informational purposes.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Plant construction in progress is comprised of costs associated with the construction of our 750,000-ton plant.&nbsp; This
plant is intended to demonstrate that the K-Fuel process works on a commercial scale and will serve as the basis for larger plants.&nbsp; The balance at December 31, 2004 includes a $1.2 million advance made to one of our vendors for the fabrication of certain
equipment, due to special payment terms pursuant to our agreement.&nbsp; Through February 28, 2005, we have received goods and services associated with the advance of $906,000.&nbsp; We anticipate receiving the remaining goods and services by the end of the second
quarter of 2005.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the quarters ended June 30, 2004 and December 31, 2004, we impaired assets of $45,000 and $1.3 million related to
certain site-specific and plant size-specific costs incurred associated with evaluating three other locations, including Black Thunder, Coal Creek and Buckskin, for our 750,000-ton plant.&nbsp; Impairments during 2003 totaled $107,000, relating primarily to scrap
metal previously believed to be salable, which was deemed to have no expected future cash value as of December&nbsp;31, 2003.&nbsp; During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, we subsequently sold the scrap metal for a gain of $31,000, which is included in Other
Income (Expense) in our Consolidated Statement of Operations.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our asset retirement obligations relate to our acquisition of Landrica and the improvements we have made at the site
related to our 750,000-ton plant.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Any adjustments will be attributed to the assets underlying the change.&nbsp; We have estimated the useful life of the asset retirement
cost of the acquired assets as the approximate weighted average expected useful life of the underlying plant assets purchased from Landrica, which approximates 12 years.&nbsp; Therefore, we began depreciating the asset on a straight-line basis over a 12-year useful
life.&nbsp; The increase in the asset retirement obligation was related to the development of our 750,00-ton plant and as a result will be amortized over the estimated useful life of the plant once it is placed into service.&nbsp; See further discussion of the asset
retirement obligation in Note 2 &ndash; Significant Accounting Policies and Note 3 &ndash; Acquisitions &ndash; Landrica Development Company.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Patent amortization expense, including abandoned patents pending, was $152,000, $264,000 and $189,000 in 2004, 2003 and 2002,
respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Most of our early patents are near their expiration dates.&nbsp; Our later patents will not expire until 2018 through 2021.&nbsp; We
have filed a new patent application covering the technology to be used in our 750,000-ton plant project, which if granted, will not expire until 2024.&nbsp; However, our on-going research and development activities often lead to new methods of applying heat and
pressure to beneficiate coal, and new patent applications may be filed for some of these new methods.&nbsp; Even as we are constructing commercial plants, we will continue our efforts to find new and better ways to improve our technology.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 7.&nbsp;DEFERRED ROYALTY COSTS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Deferred royalty costs is comprised of deferred costs related to the issuances of license for K-Fuel and a one-time payment made to Mr.
Edward Koppelman, the inventor of K-Fuel.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-13</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The deferred royalty costs associated with the issuances of licenses for K-Fuel represent the licensing fees paid to the Koppelman
estate, described below.&nbsp; Such costs are amortized over the same period as the deferred revenue related to the underlying contract.&nbsp; We did not recognize any revenue related to the license agreement with Cook Inlet Coal LLC in 2004.&nbsp; The $7.5 million
payment we received in December 2004 was deferred.&nbsp; As a result, the net costs related to the licensing fees owed to the Koppleman estate, were also deferred.&nbsp; We expect to start recognizing revenue from the Cook Inlet Coal contract in 2005 as we incur
costs associated with the transfer of our technology to Cook Inlet Coal.&nbsp; We are currently estimating these costs for 2005 and beyond and anticipate allocating a portion of the deferred revenue to current portion recognizable within the next twelve months after
each period end.&nbsp; Therefore, we have classified all of the deferred costs related to this agreement as long term as well.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In 1996, we entered into a royalty amendment agreement with Mr. Koppelman, or subsequent to his death, the Koppelman estate, that
reduced the cap for payments by $500,000 to $75.2 million and set the royalty percentage at 25% of our worldwide licensing and royalty revenue, as defined in the agreement.&nbsp; In addition, Mr. Koppelman provided us an indemnification against potential claims made
by certain parties if we licensed the technology.&nbsp; We paid Mr. Koppelman a total of $500,000 pursuant to the agreement as a prepayment.&nbsp; The $500,000 has no specified expiration date and recognition is solely dependent upon the issuance of licenses; and as
a result, has been reflected in deferred royalty costs in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.&nbsp; We entered into the agreement with Cook Inlet Coal, a significant third party licensing agreement, in December 2004.&nbsp; We are amortizing the $500,000 payment as
license revenue generated from this agreement is recognized&nbsp;&nbsp; Through December 31, 2004, we have incurred costs totaling $2.2 million, including $1.9 million paid in February 2005, pursuant to the $75.2 million cap reducing the amount payable under the cap
to $73.0 million.&nbsp; Also, see discussion in Note 15 &ndash; Commitments and Contingencies - Royalties.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following details activity related to the remaining Koppelman royalty and licenses cap (dollars in thousands):</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<div align="center">

<tr height="8">

<p><font size="2" face="Times New
Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Mr. Theodore Venners, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, is entitled to 50% of net royalties to be paid to the
Koppelman estate.&nbsp; In December 2004, Mr. Venners entered into a waiver agreement with us under which he agreed to assign his right to payments that may become due to him from the estate in connection with a license arrangement with Cook Inlet Coal, in December
2004.&nbsp; Pursuant to the waiver, Mr. Venners is obligated to remit any proceeds he may receive related to the Cook Inlet Coal license agreement to us.&nbsp; As we do not have the right to offset the amount owed to the estate against the amount we expect to receive
from the estate, we have accrued the entire amount due to the Koppelman estate in Accrued Liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.&nbsp; In addition, we have recorded a receivable in Related Party Receivable in our Consolidated Balance Sheets representing the
amount due back from the Koppelman estate.&nbsp; In February 2005, we paid the entire $1.9 million amount due to the estate and the estate remitted Mr. Venners&rsquo; portion directly back to us.&nbsp; Mr. Venners continues to negotiate a reduction, representing his
portion, in the overall amounts due to the Koppelman estate or payment of his portion through the issuance of our common stock or other securities.&nbsp; It is unclear if future negotiations will be successful in reducing our overall obligation to the estate or if
the use of securities will act as a suitable currency for payment.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 8.&nbsp;LONG-TERM DEBT</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Long-term debt consisted of the following:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr height="17">
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td colspan="6" height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="center"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">December 31</font></b></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>

<tr height="1">
<td height="1" valign="bottom"></td>
<td colspan="6" height="1" valign="bottom" bgcolor="black"></td>
<td height="1" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New
Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="8" valign="bottom"></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; At the request of the holder of the $170,000 unsecured promissory note, payments, including interest, during 2004 and 2003 were
deferred and the note became payable on demand.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-14</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In January and February 2002, we borrowed a total of $1.0 million pursuant to two agreements and comprised of a total of five unsecured
notes payable bearing interest at 10% per annum, due on June 30, 2002.&nbsp; The terms of the two agreements included warrants to purchase a total of 500,000 shares of common stock of KFx at an exercise price of $3.00 per share.&nbsp; We estimated the fair value of
the warrants and recorded a debt discount of $446,000, which was amortized to interest expense over the terms of the notes.&nbsp; We calculated the debt discount amount based upon an allocation of the proceeds to the relative fair value of the debt and
warrants.&nbsp; The estimated fair value of the January 2002 warrant was determined using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using an expected life of 3 years, expected volatility of 83%, a risk free interest rate of 3.46% and a dividend yield of zero.&nbsp; The
estimated fair value of the February 2002 warrants was also determined using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using an expected life of 3 years, expected volatility of 82%, a risk free interest rate of 3.50% and a dividend yield of zero.&nbsp; On July 1, 2002,
cash payments totaling $1.0 million were made to repay the entire obligations, except the warrants, pursuant to the notes.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 9.&nbsp;CONVERTIBLE DEBENTURES</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On July 31, 1997, we completed a private placement of unsecured convertible debentures, or the debentures.&nbsp; The
debentures had a maturity date in July 2002 at 112% of principal amount, and had an annual interest rate of 6.0 percent, payable semi-annually on January 31 and July 31.&nbsp; The debentures had conversion rights into KFx common stock at varying conversion prices at
specified dates.&nbsp; The debentures contained provisions that would reduce the conversion price if we sold or issued any equity instrument of KFx at a price below $3.75 per share.&nbsp; Additionally, the debentures were callable by us at 130% of the principal
amount.&nbsp; In connection with the placement of the debentures, we incurred costs totaling $2.4 million, which were recorded as debt issue costs and were amortized over the life of the debentures.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December 2001 and March 2002, we sold common stock in private placements for $3.00 per share and $2.50 per share,
respectively.&nbsp; These sales reduced the conversion price of the debentures.&nbsp; As a result, the difference between the new conversion price and the fair value of the our common stock on the original issuance date of the debentures resulted in a beneficial
conversion feature of $2.3 million related to the $3.00 stock sale and $802,000 related to the $2.50 stock sale.&nbsp; The beneficial conversion feature was fully amortized by July 2002, the redemption date of the debentures.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In a series of transactions in 2002, prior to the maturity date, holders of debentures exercised their right to convert their
debentures into common stock.&nbsp; Holders of debentures with a face value of $3.5 million converted their debentures at a conversion price of $3.00 per share into 1.2 million shares of common stock.&nbsp; Holders of debentures with a face value of $1.0 million
converted their debentures at a conversion price of $2.50 per share into 400,000 shares of common stock.&nbsp; As a result of these conversions, $5.0 million, including a pro rata portion of accreted maturity premium, net of a pro rata portion of deferred debt issue
costs, was credited to common stock and Additional Paid in Capital.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On July 24, 2002, we satisfied the remaining obligation of $3.5 million for the outstanding debentures, which included accrued interest
and a 12% maturity premium.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><a name="OLE_LINK6"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 10.&nbsp;STOCKHOLDERS&rsquo; EQUITY</font></b></a></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Preferred Stock</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are authorized to issue up to 20 million shares of preferred stock with a par value of $.001.&nbsp; Pursuant to our charter, our
Board of Directors, without shareholder approval, has the authority to (1) create one or more classes or series of preferred stock; (2) issue shares of preferred stock in such classes or series up to the maximum of 20 million shares; and (3) determine all rights,
privileges, preferences and restrictions of any such class or series of preferred stock, including dividend rights, voting rights, redemption rights, liquidation preferences and conversion rights.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2004 and 2003, no shares of preferred stock
were issued or outstanding.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are limited by the terms of a common stock and warrant purchase agreement for the sale of certain shares in 2002.&nbsp; Under the
terms of this agreement and a related investors rights agreement, we are prohibited from selling and issuing any of our preferred stock until the investors no longer hold any shares of common stock or warrants, or obtain a waiver to sell and issue preferred stock
from at least two-thirds of these investors.&nbsp; The terms of this agreement also provide anti-dilution protections to these investors that are triggered if we sell common stock at a price below $2.50 per share.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Common Stock</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are authorized to issue up to 120 million shares of common stock with a par value of $.001.&nbsp; There were 64.8 million and 53.0
million shares of common stock issued and outstanding as of December 31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-15</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><a name="OLE_LINK7"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the second quarter of 2004, we sold 245,400 shares of common stock to Arch Coal, Inc. for gross proceeds of
approximately $2 million and incurred $5,000 in placement costs.&nbsp; We used these proceeds for general corporate purposes.&nbsp; On November 24, 2004, we issued and sold 4,000,000 shares of our common stock at $12.00 per share in a private placement to a limited
number of accredited investors.&nbsp; The gross proceeds received from the financing were $48.0 million.&nbsp; We paid a placement fee equal to 5% of the gross proceeds and incurred an additional $241,000.&nbsp; As a result, we recorded an increase to our Additional
Paid in Capital of $45.4 million related to this placement in our December 31, 2004 Consolidated Balance Sheet.&nbsp; We anticipate using the net proceeds from this placement as follows (dollars in thousands):</font></a></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In two transactions in March 2003, we issued a total of 7.7 million shares of KFx common stock at a price of $2.50 per share and
warrants to purchase 1.5 million shares of KFx common stock, which resulted in cash proceeds to us of $19.4 million.&nbsp; The warrants have an exercise price of $2.75 per share, are subject to adjustment, and are exercisable over a five-year period.&nbsp; The
warrants were recorded at their estimated fair value of $2.4 million.&nbsp; The estimated fair value of all of the warrants was determined using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using an expected life of 5 years and a dividend yield of zero.&nbsp; Expected
volatility of 73% and 72% and a risk free interest rate of 2.6% and 3.1% related to 6.0 million shares and 1.7 million shares, respectively.&nbsp; Through the effective date of the registration statement of May 5, 2003, $2.8 million of additional expense was
recognized for the increase in fair value of the warrants.&nbsp; This amount was recorded as additional paid in capital at the effective date of registration.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the period from March 28, 2002 through August 21, 2002, we entered into five separate transactions with certain investors, or
the Investment Agreements, whereby we issued 6.8 million shares at $2.50 per share and warrants for 14.4 million shares of our common stock.&nbsp; Cash to us from these transactions was $16.9 million.&nbsp; The warrants have an exercise price of $2.75 and expire in
March through August 2010.&nbsp; See Note 12 &ndash; Warrants for further discussion.&nbsp; The investors also received a redemption right that would have become effective July 24, 2003, but was later cancelled by the investors on December 19, 2002.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As part of the Investment Agreements, we were required to register the shares and the warrants purchased by the investors, or we would
have been required to issue additional warrants.&nbsp; However, effective July 19, 2002, the investors agreed to waive the registration effectiveness requirement in exchange for an increase in warrants, from 112.5% to 212.5% times the number of shares purchased for
all of the transactions.&nbsp; Prior to the effectiveness of the registration statement, and until the effectiveness requirement was cancelled, we were required to record other expense of $2.8 million, based on a Black-Scholes option-pricing model for the effect of
these penalty warrant obligations.&nbsp; Under accounting rules this charge was not reversed when the penalty warrant provision terminated.&nbsp; The five transactions are summarized as follows:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<div align="center">

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The investors have the right under certain conditions to develop or participate in the greater of K-Fuel commercial
projects with an annual output capacity of 50 million tons per year or six commercial projects.&nbsp; The rights granted to the investors also gave them the exclusive right to develop commercial projects in India for an indefinite period of time as long as certain
conditions are met.&nbsp; Additionally, the investors received a right of first refusal to market K-Fuel</font><sup><font size="2" color="black"></font></sup><font size="2">in the United States should we decide to pursue marketing arrangements with third
parties.&nbsp; Finally, one of the investors received the right to select two persons to serve on the Board of Directors of KFx.&nbsp; As a result, Richard Spencer, manager of Westcliff Capital Management LLC, was added to our Board of Directors.&nbsp; This provision
remains in force until the investors hold less than 400,000 shares of KFx&rsquo;s common stock.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-16</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As noted above, due to the delay in meeting the registration requirement of the investment transactions, KFx was required
to issue additional warrants.&nbsp; Because there was no cap on the number of additional warrants to be issued until the registration statement became effective, the value of the warrants that were issued in the March 28</font><sup><font size="2" color=
"black">th</font></sup><font size="2" color="black">, April 30</font><sup><font size="2" color="black">th</font></sup><font size="2" color="black">and July 1</font><sup><font size="2" color="black">st</font></sup><font size="2" color="black">transactions were valued
using a Black-Scholes option pricing model and recorded as a liability on KFx&rsquo;s balance sheet.&nbsp; The table below summarizes the values used in the Black-Scholes model for each of the three transactions.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The difference for each transaction was originally recorded as redeemable common stock, net of debt issuance costs.&nbsp; When the
registration statement was declared effective on August 30, 2002, the warrants were adjusted to their estimated fair value on that date.&nbsp; The table below summarizes the values used in the Black-Scholes model to determine the estimated fair values of the warrants
issued.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>
