<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="10" valign="bottom">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The $4.2 million difference between the estimated fair value of the warrants at June 30, 2002, and their issue date if later, and the
fair value of the warrants at August 30, 2002 was included in other expense in the Consolidated Statement of Operations.&nbsp; At August 30, 2002, upon effectiveness of the registration statement, the total estimated fair value of the warrants of $21.5 million was
reclassified to equity.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In May 2002, we entered into an agreement to issue 100,000 shares of KFx common stock and issued a warrant to purchase 113,000 shares
of KFx common stock with an exercise price of $2.75 per share expiring 8 years from the date of issuance, with Eastgate Management Corporation, or Eastgate, in exchange for a $250,000 full recourse note, which matured on February 1, 2003.&nbsp; The fair value of the
common stock on the date of the agreement was $270,000 and the warrant had an estimated fair value of $218,000.&nbsp; The estimated fair value of the warrant was determined using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using an expected life of 8 years, expected
volatility of 67%, a risk free interest rate of 4.9% and a dividend yield of zero.&nbsp; In conjunction with the agreement for the sale of common stock and issuance of the warrant, we entered into an additional agreement with Eastgate to provide consulting services
to us over a 10-month period ending February 2003 for $250,000.&nbsp; As a result of the fair value of the common stock and warrant being more determinable than the consulting services, we recorded the common stock and the warrant at their estimated fair value.&nbsp;
The difference between the estimated fair value of the common stock and warrant, less the</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-17</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$250,000 note receivable, was recorded to deferred compensation for consulting services.&nbsp; We offset the note receivable against the cost of consulting services.&nbsp; We amortized the original outstanding amount of the
note and the deferred compensation for the consultant of $488,000 over the 10-month consulting services agreement, which expired in February 2003.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In a series of transactions during the second half of 2002, we issued 1.2 million shares of our common stock at a price of $2.50 per
share and warrants to purchase 2.5 million shares of common stock, which resulted in cash proceeds to us of $2.9 million.&nbsp; The warrants have an exercise price of $2.75 per share and expire 8 years from the date of issuance.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In July 2001, we sold 1,000,000 shares of our common stock at a price of $3.65 per share and issued a warrant to purchase 500,000
shares of common stock with an exercise price of $3.65 per share expiring three years from the date of issuance, to an institutional investor, resulting in proceeds to us of $3.5 million, net of transaction costs.&nbsp; In conjunction with this investment, we issued
a warrant, expiring three years after the date of issue, exercisable for 100,000 shares of our common stock, at a price of $3.65 per share, subject to certain adjustments, to an advisor to the transaction.&nbsp; In June 2002, we reduced the exercise price of the
warrant to $3.00 per share and extended the exercise period of the warrant by an additional two years from the original issuance date.&nbsp; As a result of the modification of the terms of the warrant, the difference between the fair value of the modified warrant and
the fair value of the warrant immediately prior to modification was estimated at $399,000 and is reflected in the Consolidated Statement of Operations as a &ldquo;Deemed dividend attributable to warrant holder.&rdquo;&nbsp; The fair value of the modified warrant was
estimated at $805,000 using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using a remaining expected life of 4.1 years, expected volatility of 78%, a risk free interest rate of 4% and a dividend yield of zero.&nbsp; The fair value of the warrant immediately prior to
modification was estimated at $406,000 using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using a remaining expected life of 2.1 years, expected volatility of 65%, a risk free interest rate of 3.2% and a dividend yield of zero.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2001, we issued 141,000 shares of common stock, which was previously presented as redeemable common stock on the balance sheet
to an investment banker in return for services rendered.&nbsp; The common stock was redeemable for cash at the option of the holder at the greater of $3.00 per share or the weighted-average fair market value of our common stock for the preceding fifteen days.&nbsp;
The stock was only redeemable after we consummated a qualifying equity transaction, which occurred on March 28, 2002 (see above).&nbsp; On September 5, 2002, the holder of the stock waived its put option relating to this stock and the redemption value of the common
stock was reclassified to equity.&nbsp; Pursuant to the waiver agreement, we issued a warrant for 180,000 shares of our common stock.&nbsp; The warrant is exercisable at $2.75 per share and expires 5 years from the date of grant.&nbsp; We estimated the fair value of
the warrant and recorded $184,000 as general and administrative expense on the issuance date.&nbsp; The estimated fair value of the warrant was determined using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model using an expected life of 5 years, expected volatility of 73%, a risk
free interest rate of 2.9% and a dividend yield of zero.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 11.&nbsp;STOCK OPTION PLANS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have five qualified stock option plans: the Amended and Restated Stock Option Plan, or the 1992 Plan; the 1996 Stock
Option and Incentive Plan, or the 1996 Plan; the 1999 Stock Incentive Plan, or the 1999 Plan; the 2002 Stock Incentive Plan, or the 2002 Plan and the 2004 Equity Incentive Plan, or the 2004 Plan.&nbsp; These plans are administered by the Compensation Committee of our
Board of Directors, or the Committee, which has the authority to determine the specific terms of awards under these plans, including grant price, vesting and term, subject to certain restrictions of the Internal Revenue Code regarding incentive stock options, or
ISOs.&nbsp; The Committee has approved the 2004 Plan but the stockholders have not approved the plan.&nbsp; The 2004 Plan will be included in our Proxy Statement for the 2005 Annual Meeting of Stockholders to be considered for approval by stockholders.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The option plans provide for the award to our executive officers and other key employees, non-employee directors and
consultants and others of Non-Qualified Stock Options, or NSOs, ISOs, stock appreciation rights, or SARs, and restricted stock, except the 1992 plan which does not allow for the issuance of SARs or restricted stock.&nbsp; Stock options granted under the option plans
generally vest 20 percent on the date of grant, with an additional 20 percent vesting on each anniversary date thereafter until fully vested.&nbsp; The Committee can accelerate the vesting of an outstanding option at its sole discretion.&nbsp; Only the 1992 Plan
contains provisions requiring the acceleration of vesting of all outstanding options outstanding under the plan in the event of a change in control, as defined in the plan.&nbsp; Stock options granted under the option plans generally expire not more than ten years
from the date of grant.&nbsp; All plans have been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission except for the 1992 Plan and the 2004 Plan.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, we have issued&nbsp; stock options related to various compensation and fee agreements with directors,
employees and outside consultants that were not issued pursuant to our five option plans.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-18</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom">
<p align="right"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the year ended December 31, 2003, we recognized&nbsp; $467,000 of compensation expense related to the 72,500 shares issued
during 2003, or shortly thereafter, for two officers and $224,000 of general and administrative expenses for the 35,000 shares issued to two consultants.&nbsp; During 2004, we granted an additional 12,500 shares to one of the officers and one of the consultants as
certain performance criteria were met.&nbsp; As a result, we recorded $44,000 of compensation expense related to 7,500 shares and $76,192 of general and administrative expense related to 5,000 shares.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, during 2004 we granted 100,000 restricted shares and 3,000 unrestricted shares from our 2002 Plan to our former President
and Chief Operating Officer and to our Chief Financial Officer, respectively.&nbsp; The restricted share grant vests pro-rata at 20% per year beginning in January 2005.&nbsp; In December 2004, we granted 86,000 shares pursuant to the 2004 Plan to a new officer.&nbsp;
As stockholders have not approved this plan, measurement date is not fixed and as a result, we are required to record compensation expense reflecting the excess of the fair value over the exercise price of the options granted.&nbsp; As a result, for the year ended
December 31, 2004, we recorded $95,000 of compensation expense, which is reflected in general and administrative expenses in our Consolidated Statement of Operations.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In November 2004 and again in February 2005, the Committee voted to extend the exercise periods for vested options for a period of 90
days after the resignation of a director and our former President and Chief Operating Officer, respectively.&nbsp; As a result of these extensions, we recorded additional general and administrative expense of $136,000 in 2004 related to the extension of 40,000
options and $906,000 in 2005 related to the extension of 120,000 options.&nbsp; The expense represents the difference between the fair value of the options on the date the extension was granted and the exercise price.&nbsp; When our former President and Chief
Operating Officer resigned, he forfeited 480,000 options and 80,000 shares of restricted stock.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In February 2005, we granted a total of 1,000,000 options to our new President and Chief Operating Officer.&nbsp; All of the options
are considered inducement options as defined by the American Stock Exchange and are not issued pursuant to a plan and vest 20% per year beginning in January 2006.&nbsp;&nbsp; At any time prior to January 2006, the Committee has the right to terminate 400,000 options
if our President and COO if certain criteria are not met.&nbsp; As the number of options and exercise price are fixed and the exercise price was equal to or greater than the fair value of the options on the date of grant, there is no compensation expense associated
with these options.&nbsp; Pursuant to the option agreement, we are required to register such options the next time we register shares for any other purpose.&nbsp; Additionally, in March 2005, the Committee approved the grant of 100,000 share of restricted stock from
the 2002 Plan, such stock grant vests 20% per year beginning January 2006.&nbsp; Lastly, in March 2005, we granted 250,000 options from our plans to our new Senior Vice President and General Counsel from the 2002 Plan.&nbsp; The options vest 20% annually beginning in
March 2006.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
F-19</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

period ending December 31, 2004:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In previous periods, we disclosed options and SARs converted to options separately.&nbsp; However, for each period in the three years
ended December 31, 2004, all options outstanding and exercisable are included in the table above.&nbsp; The amounts outstanding and exercisable were adjusted by 1.5 million SARs converted to options as of December 31, 2003.&nbsp; See further discussion of the SARs
below.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; All stock options granted during each of the three years ended December 31, 2004 were at exercise prices that were equal to or greater
than the fair market value of our common stock on the date of grant.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Stock Appreciation Rights</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the second half of 1999, our Board of Directors adopted a policy of granting stock-based compensation to directors in lieu of
directors&rsquo; fees.&nbsp; During 2001, SARs for 325,000 shares at a price of $1.38 per share were granted to directors pursuant to the 1999 Plan.&nbsp; Additionally, we granted SARs for 524,000 shares and 50,000 shares at $2.25 and $2.70 per share to employees and
consultants, respectively, pursuant to the 1999 plan.&nbsp; The SARs prices were equal to or greater than our closing stock price on the dates of grant and the SARs were generally fully vested at the date of grant.&nbsp; Outstanding SARs became exercisable on July
24, 2002, upon our repayment of the debentures.&nbsp; SARs granted to directors expire in ten years and those granted to consultants generally expire five years from date of grant.&nbsp; The SARs granted to employees expired thirty days after the debentures were
retired.&nbsp; Upon exercise of any of the SARs, we had the option of (a) paying the stock appreciation in excess of the grant price in cash, (b) converting the SAR to a non-qualified stock option for the same number of shares as covered by the SAR at the
SAR</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-20</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">grant price, or (c) granting our common stock with a value at the date of exercise equivalent to the amount of stock appreciation at the date of exercise.&nbsp; During 2001, 180,000 SARs pursuant to the 1999 Plan were
cancelled.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Since the SARs were exercisable, we recorded $2.1 million as general and administrative expense for the SARs based upon the number of
SARs exercisable at June 30, 2002, multiplied by the difference between the fair value of KFx common stock ($2.55 at June 30, 2002) and the exercise price of the respective SARs.&nbsp; During the quarter ended September 30, 2002, SARs for 245,000 shares of KFx common
stock were exercised for options in the 1999 Plan.&nbsp; These SARs were adjusted to their intrinsic value on the date of exercise, resulting in a decrease of $29,000 in general and administrative expense.&nbsp; At September 30, 2002, the remaining outstanding SARs
were adjusted to their intrinsic value of $1.2 million, based on the fair value of KFx common stock ($2.00 at September 30, 2002), resulting in a decrease of $860,000 in general and administrative expense.&nbsp; During the quarter ended December 31, 2002, SARs for
1.6 million shares of KFx common stock were exercised for options in the 1999 Plan.&nbsp; These SARs were adjusted to their intrinsic value on the date of exercise, resulting in an increase of $582,000 in general and administrative expense.&nbsp; At December 31,
2002, 158,000 outstanding SARs were exercised for options in the 1996 Plan and adjusted to their intrinsic value of $233,000, based on the fair value of KFx common stock ($2.59 at December 31, 2002), resulting in an increase of $73,000 in general and administrative
expense.&nbsp; SARs that were exercised into plan options during 2002 were satisfied with the issuance of stock options from the 1996 or 1999 Plan with an exercise price equal to the exercise price of the respective SAR.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In January 2003, the remaining 20,000 outstanding SARs were exercised for options in the 1999 Plan.&nbsp; During the time in January
that these SARs were outstanding we recognized approximately $2,000 in expense related to their adjustment to intrinsic value.&nbsp; In 2003, 486,000 of these options were exercised at a weighted average price of $1.81, which generated proceeds to us of approximately
$879,000.&nbsp; The remaining 1.5 million SARs exercised for stock options expire three years from the date of issuance.&nbsp; No SAR&rsquo;s were granted to directors, employees or consultants in 2004, 2003 or 2002.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 12.&nbsp;WARRANTS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Associated with various financing transactions and professional service agreements, we have issued transferable warrants to purchase
common stock, which generally, immediately vest.&nbsp; The following table summarizes the outstanding warrant activity for years ended December 31, 2004, 2003, and 2002:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On June&nbsp;25, 2004, we entered into agreements to raise capital proceeds from two of our warrant holders.&nbsp; In return for
1.3 million additional warrants at an exercise price of $11.00 per share, these warrant holders agreed to exercise 3.9 million of their warrants before their contractual exercise date.&nbsp; On June&nbsp;28, 2004, we received $7.2 million of proceeds from the
exercise of 2.6 million of these warrants.&nbsp; As a direct cost of this transaction, we decreased additional paid-in capital by $1.2 million, which was equal to the Black-Scholes value of the 900,000 additional warrants issued, and increased additional paid-in
capital by the same amount for the value of the additional warrants issued.&nbsp; On July 22, 2004, we received $3.4 million of proceeds from the exercise of the remaining 1.3 million warrants from the other warrant holder.&nbsp; As a cost of this transaction, we
decreased additional paid-in capital by $600,000, which was equal to the Black-Scholes value of the 415,000 additional warrants issued, and increased additional paid-in capital by the same amount for the value of the additional warrants issued.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-21</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Warrant rights for 1.5 million shares of our common stock were granted to the investors in our March 2003 private equity
transactions.&nbsp; The warrants are exercisable at a price of $2.75 per common share, are subject to adjustment and are exercisable over a five-year period.&nbsp; See Note 10 &ndash; Stockholders&rsquo; Equity for further discussion.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In May 2003, we issued a warrant for the purchase of 1.0 million shares of our common stock at an exercise price of $2.75 per share to
a consultant as part of a three-year services agreement.&nbsp; The warrant vests as follows: (i) 2/9ths or 222,000 shares vested on the date of the agreement, March 1, 2003 and (ii) remaining warrants vest 1/36, or 28,000 on the first day of each month thereafter for
a total of 28 months.&nbsp; At December 31, 2004, the right to purchase approximately 778,000 of our common shares had vested under this services agreement.&nbsp; We recognized $950,000 and $1.3 million of expense for these services during 2004 and 2003,
respectively, based on the fair value of the warrants that vested during each year.&nbsp; Additionally in November 2003, we granted a warrant to this consultant for the purchase of 100,000 shares of our common stock at an exercise price of $2.75.&nbsp; We recognized
an additional $148,000 in general and administrative expenses for the granting of this warrant based on the fair value of the underlying stock on the date of grant.&nbsp; We also granted a warrant to an investment banking company during the year.&nbsp; At the date of
issuance, the exercise price of the 100,000 warrant was greater than the market price of our common stock.&nbsp; Therefore, we recognized no additional expense for the issuance of this warrant.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Warrants granted in 2002 related to private investment transactions, financing transactions and certain professional service
expenses.&nbsp; See Note 8 &ndash; Long-term Debt and Note 10 &ndash; Stockholders&rsquo; Equity for further discussion.</font></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 13.&nbsp;DISCONTINUED PEGASUS OPERATIONS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On November 26, 2003, we completed an equity exchange transaction with Kennecott.&nbsp; In accordance with terms contained in the
Equity Exchange Agreement, or the Agreement, Kennecott transferred to us its 49% membership interest in KFL and the full ownership of all related technology developed by Kennecott.&nbsp; Prior to the consummation of this transaction, we owned a 51% membership
interest in KFL.&nbsp; In exchange, we transferred our ownership interests in Pegasus to Kennecott.&nbsp; We had previously held a 65% ownership in Pegasus.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In connection with the Agreement, we paid $500,000 to Pavilion to obtain agreement from Pavilion to waive their right to demand
acceleration of royalty obligations due to Pavilion from Pegasus upon the change in control of Pegasus.&nbsp; We are to be repaid 50% of this amount as part of the note receivable from Pegasus and the remaining 50% was included in the contingent obligations due from
Pegasus.&nbsp; See Note 4 &ndash; Note Receivable for further discussion.&nbsp; Kennecott also received a license and all necessary rights to build and operate up to three commercial K-Fuel plants and to market K-Fuel or other production from those plants.&nbsp; Each
plant can have annual capacity of up to three million tons and Kennecott will pay applicable royalty and license fees for these three plants.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Additionally, as part of this transaction, an intercompany working capital loan from KFx to Pegasus with an outstanding balance of $9.4
million was exchanged for a contingent earn-out agreement of up to $9.4 million in the aggregate, plus accrued interest (prime rate plus 500 basis points), payable out of a portion of future cash flows generated by Pegasus.&nbsp; Due to the contingent nature of this
potential stream of future cash flows, we have not recognized an asset or any associated income.&nbsp; Through December 31, 2004, we have not received any payments pursuant to the earn-out agreement.&nbsp; Pursuant to the terms of the Agreement, Kennecott repaid KFx
approximately $1 million, plus accrued interest, that KFx had loaned to Pegasus during the first nine months of 2003, under this working capital line of credit.&nbsp; Kennecott also paid our Chairman and CEO $185,000 to retire indebtedness owed by Pegasus and
$301,000 to one of our directors and his company to retire indebtedness owed by Pegasus.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following table presents the summarized results of Pegasus&rsquo; discontinued operations for the Consolidated Statement of
Operations for the year ended December 31, 2002 and the period from January 1, 2003 through November 26, 2003 (date of exchange transaction).</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<div align="center">
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">

<p align="center"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">Period Ended<br />
 November 26, 2003</font></b></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom"></td>
<td colspan="2" height="17" valign="bottom">

</font></b> <b><font size="1">December 31, 2002</font></b></p>
</td>

<tr height="17">
<td height="17" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Revenue</font></p>
</td>
<td height="17" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-22</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 14.&nbsp;SUPPLEMENTAL CASH FLOW INFORMATION</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We did not revise the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows for the years ended December 31, 2002 for discontinued operations.&nbsp;
However, we changed the presentation to reflect the reduction of the net cash (used) or provided by discontinued operations from the net increase or (decrease) in cash for the period.&nbsp; Deducting this net cash number provides reconciliation to the revised cash
balance per the Consolidated Balance Sheet at December 31, 2002.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The following table summarizes certain supplemental cash flow information for the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and
2002:</font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Year Ended December 31,2004</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2004, we recognized $3.6 million of non-cash expense, of which $544,000 was pursuant to an agreement with a related party,
associated with the issuance of stock, warrants, and options to various consultants.&nbsp; Approximately $2.1 million of expense, including $544,000 payable to related parties, relates to services for certain governmental and environmental consultants.&nbsp; See
further discussion in Note &ndash; 15 &ndash; Commitments and Note 17 &ndash; Related Parties.&nbsp; The remaining $1.5 million relates to various services provided by several different consultants.&nbsp; See further discussion of the $157,000 compensation expense
related to employees and directors in Note11 &ndash; Stock Option Plans.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Year Ended December 31, 2003</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Convertible debt with an outstanding balance of $2.4 million was converted into 871,000 shares of common stock at a conversion price of
$2.75 per share on September 11, 2003.&nbsp; In connection with this conversion, we recorded additional interest expense of $627,000 during the year to write-off the debt discount associated with this convertible debt.&nbsp; As a result of the exchange transaction,
described in Note 13 &ndash; Discontinued Pegasus Operations, the balance of this note is now due to us from Pegasus.&nbsp; The details of this note are more fully described in Note 4 &ndash; Note Receivable.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On July 1, 2003, Landrica returned 450,000 shares of common stock and 1,300,000 warrants to purchase our common stock.&nbsp; There was
no cash consideration paid by us to Landrica in connection with this transaction.&nbsp; We reduced Common Stock and increased Additional Paid in Capital by the par value of these shares returned or $450.&nbsp; The warrants had not been exercised and were cancelled
upon return.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-23</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During 2003, we recognized expense of $2.4 million related to services performed by consultants settled with securities.&nbsp; This
expense is comprised of the following services:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We issued 53,000 and 20,000 of our common shares for a total value of approximately $240,000 to two different consultants for financial reporting and general transactional services and engineering services, respectively.&nbsp;
We recognized an expense of $240,000 payable in cash to one of these consultants as of December 31, 2003, for additional financial reporting and general transactional services.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We recognized $448,000 on issuance of 100,000 options, with an exercise price of $6.39, for engineering services.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We issued 30,000 common shares and a warrant for the right to purchase 1.0 million of our common shares at an exercise price of $2.75.&nbsp; The warrant vests as follows: (i) 2/9ths or 222,000 shares vested on the date of the
agreement, March 1, 2003 and (ii) remaining warrants vest 1/36, or 28,000 on the first day of each month thereafter for a total of 28 months.&nbsp; We recognized $1.3 million of indirect fund-raising expense for these services during 2003 based on the fair value of
the warrants that vested during the year.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The remaining $364,000 of non-cash expense relates to options for financial advisory, engineering and other services performed during 2003.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Year Ended December 31, 2002</font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Convertible debentures with a principal value of $3.5 million were converted, based on a conversion price of $3.00 per share, into 1.2
million shares of common stock, which resulted in a reduction to stockholders&rsquo; deficit of $3.8 million, including a pro rata portion of accreted maturity premium and net of a pro rata portion of unamortized debt issue costs.&nbsp; Convertible debentures with a
principal value of $1.0 million were converted, based on a conversion price of $2.50 per share, into 400,000 shares of our common stock, which resulted in a reduction to stockholders&rsquo; deficit of $1.1 million, including a pro rata portion of accreted maturity
premium and net of a pro rata portion of unamortized debt issue costs.&nbsp; See Note 9 &ndash; Convertible Debentures for further discussion.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; During the first quarter of 2002, we sold common stock in a private placement transaction, which reduced the conversion price of the
convertible debentures to $2.50 per share.&nbsp; The reduction of the conversion price resulted in a beneficial conversion feature charge of $802,000, which was recorded as debt discount and a reduction to stockholders&rsquo; deficit. &nbsp; The debt discount was
amortized to interest expense over the remaining life of the convertible debentures.&nbsp; See Note 9 &ndash; Convertible Debentures for further discussion.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Due to the conversion and repayment of all of the convertible debentures during the third quarter of 2002, the conversion price of the
convertible long-term debt was reset to $2.75 per share.&nbsp; The reduction of the conversion price resulted in a beneficial conversion feature charge of $1.1 million, which was recorded as a debt discount and a reduction to stockholders&rsquo; deficit.&nbsp; The
debt discount was amortized to interest expense over the estimated remaining term of the convertible debt.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We issued warrants to purchase 500,000 shares of our common stock in conjunction with the notes payable issued during the first quarter
of 2002, resulting in debt discount of $446,000, which was amortized to interest expense through the maturity of the notes on June 30, 2002.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We issued warrants to purchase 14.4 million shares of our common stock in conjunction with private placements  of our common stock
during the year, resulting in accretion expense of $15.1 million.&nbsp; See Note 10 &ndash; Shareholders&rsquo; Equity for further discussion.&nbsp; We were also obligated to issue additional warrants to purchase 1.9 million shares of&nbsp; our common stock through
the date the registration statement was deemed effective, resulting in other expense of $2.8 million.&nbsp; In September 2002, the investors agreed to waive their rights to receive these additional warrants, thus the warrants were not issued.&nbsp; However, the $2.8
charge that was recorded as other expense was not reversed.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We issued 387,000 shares of our common stock with a fair value of $966,00, of which 30,000 of these shares were issued to a related
party of the Chairman and CEO, in exchange for consulting services during the year and to satisfy an obligation that existed at December 31, 2001.&nbsp; Accordingly, $821,000 was charged to general and administrative expense and $50,000 reduced a liability
outstanding at December 31, 2001 and $95,0000 is recorded as equity as of December 31, 2002 and was expensed in 2003.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Note 15.&nbsp;Commitments And Contingent Liabilities</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This table does not include accounts payable or accrued expenses, which are reported in our December 31, 2004 Consolidated Balance
Sheets.&nbsp; We also have not included the interest related to the $170,000 demand note payable.&nbsp; We have included our non-cancelable purchase orders in the 750,000-ton plant commitments.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have excluded payments to be made to the Koppelman estate, as we cannot presently determine when such payments will be made as such
payments are based upon our receipt of cash for licensing and royalties.</font></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Operating Leases</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We are obligated under non-cancelable operating leases with initial terms exceeding one year relating to office space and certain
equipment and vehicle leases.&nbsp; Rent expense in the year ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 was $223,000, $255,000 and $284,000, respectively.&nbsp; Through September 30, 2004 certain of the leased property, principally office space was sublet to third
parties under a non-cancelable operating sublease.&nbsp; Such sub-lease agreement expired on September 30, 2004.&nbsp; Sublease income was $124,000, $143,000 and $181,000 for the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Purchase Commitment Obligations</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have purchase commitments for the 750,000-ton plant-related equipment and services of approximately $3.5 million as of
December&nbsp;31, 2004.&nbsp; Additionally, we have previously negotiated purchase commitments of approximately $1.2 million for corporate, engineering and government relations consulting services over the next five years, including the government relations
consulting discussed in further detail below.</font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></b></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Litigation</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>Leon S. Segen, derivatively on behalf of KFx v. Westcliff Capital Management, LLC, Richard S. Spencer III, KFx Inc. and others,
United States District Court Southern District of New York, filed March&nbsp;7, 2003</i>.&nbsp; A stockholder suing derivatively on our behalf filed a civil complaint against Westcliff Capital Management, LLC, Richard S. Spencer, a member of our Board, KFx and others
pursuant to Section 16(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 for disgorgement of alleged short-swing profits of at least $5.3 million purported to have arisen in connection with a series of transactions between us and certain investors completed in 2002.&nbsp;
The action sought disgorgement of profits, interest, attorneys&rsquo; fees and costs.&nbsp; Based on settlements negotiated between KFx and the other defendants, the court granted the defendants&rsquo; motion for summary judgment on January&nbsp;20, 2004 and
dismissed all claims with prejudice.&nbsp; The plaintiff, Leon S. Segen, derivatively on behalf of KFx, filed a notice of appeal on January&nbsp;29, 2004.&nbsp; The matter was settled before final arguments were presented to the Court of Appeals.&nbsp; KFx received
$185,000 from the other defendants under the court approved settlement agreements and paid fees of $28,000 to the plaintiff as its share of the settlement expense.&nbsp; The net proceeds of $157,000 are included in other income for the year ended December 31,
2004.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As with most businesses, there could be potential lawsuits incidental to our business, none of which are anticipated to have a material
adverse impact on our financial position, results of operations, liquidity or cash flows.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Royalties</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As described in further detail in Note 7 &ndash; Deferred Royalty Costs, we entered into a royalty amendment agreement
with Mr. Edward Koppelman, the inventor of the K-Fuel technology.&nbsp; Pursuant to the agreement we owe Mr. Koppelman&rsquo;s estate 25% of our worldwide royalty and license fee revenue, as defined in the agreement, subject to a $75.2 million cap.&nbsp; Through
December 31, 2004, we have incurred costs totaling $2.2 million, including $1.9 million to be paid in 2005, pursuant to the $75.2 million cap</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-25</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">reducing the amount payable under the cap to $73.0 million.&nbsp; In addition, Mr. Theodore Venners our Chairman and CEO<font color="black">, is entitled to 50% of net distributable royalties to be paid by the
Koppelman estate.&nbsp; In December 2004, Mr. Venners</font> entered into a waiver agreement with us under which he agreed to assign his right to payments that may become due to him from the estate in connection with the Cook Inlet Coal license arrangement.&nbsp;
Pursuant to the waiver, Mr. Venners is obligated to remit any proceeds he may receive related to the Cook Inlet Coal license agreement to us.&nbsp; See further discussion in Note 7 &ndash; Prepaid Royalty.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Fort Union Ltd. is entitled to 20% of North American royalty revenue until the earlier of cumulative royalties paid of
$1.5 million or September 15, 2015.&nbsp; Through December 31, 2004, we have not yet paid anything to Fort Union Ltd.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Ohio Valley Electric is entitled to 0.5% of royalty revenue generated based upon an older version of our K-Fuel
technology.&nbsp; While we believe that Ohio Valley Electric is not entitled to any royalty revenue generated based upon the current version of our technology, we can provide no assurance that they will not pursue options to compel us to pay them a royalty based upon
the new technology.&nbsp; There is no expiration date or cap associated with this royalty.&nbsp; Through December 31, 2004, we have not yet paid anything to Ohio Valley Electric.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Consulting Agreements</font></i></b></p>

<p><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></i></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have agreements with consultants that advise us on proposed legislation and regulations and advocate our interests before the U.S.
Congress and regulatory agencies.&nbsp; Some of these agreements provided for bonus compensation if certain legislation favorable to KFx was enacted by Congress.&nbsp; Congress recently passed H.R. 4520 that was signed into law on October&nbsp;22, 2004.&nbsp; Based
on a preliminary review by our tax counsel, the law could provide a tax credit of approximately $5.35 per ton (as escalated for inflation) for each ton of K-Fuel produced from plants placed into service before January&nbsp;1, 2009 for a period of 10 years from such
in-service date.&nbsp; Under this law, our initial 750,000-ton plant could generate approximately $4 million per year of tax credits, while a more optimum sized facility at 8 million tons per year would generate over $42 million per year of tax credits for the
applicable 10-year period.&nbsp; There are specific qualifications that must be met for a product to qualify for the tax credit and the credit is subject to a &ldquo;phase out&rdquo; formula that, under certain circumstances, could reduce or eliminate the tax
credit.&nbsp; While we believe these tax credits will provide significant value to us, there can be no assurances that we will receive these benefits.&nbsp; See further discussion in Note 17 &ndash; Related Party Transactions</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; As a result of H.R. 4520 establishing certain tax credits, we are required to (1) make cash payments of approximately $100,000, (2)
extend four of the currently active consulting agreements for periods of 12 to 43 months at an aggregate cost of $1.1 million, (3) issue 19,300 shares of common stock for services provided, and (4) issue warrants for the purchase of a total of 600,000 shares at an
average exercise price of $7.35 per share with a term of three years.&nbsp; We expensed $100,000 in general and administrative expenses related to the issuance of the shares of common stock.&nbsp; The proceeds to us from the exercise of these warrants would be $4.4
million and the non-cash expense, based on the Black-Scholes option-pricing model (assuming a weighted average risk free interest rate of 2.83%, expected option life of 3 years, expected volatility of 46.6% and no dividends), for issuing these warrants was $2.1
million, which was reflected in our Results of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2004.&nbsp; The $100,000 cash payment was made in January 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
F-26</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />

Deferred tax assets (liabilities) were comprised of the following:</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tr>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Non-deductible items and other includes $3.4 million of adjustments to the 2003 provision for items not previously deducted for tax basis purposes that were taken in the 2003 net operating loss.</font></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have recorded a valuation allowance for the full amount of our net deferred asset because, based upon an assessment of both
negative and positive evidence, it is more like than not that we will not realize such benefits in future tax returns.&nbsp; Our tax return net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $73 million expire in various amounts beginning in 2005.&nbsp; Certain
limitations apply to the annual amount of net operating losses that can be used to offset taxable income, after certain ownership changes, as defined in Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code, or Section 382.&nbsp; Pursuant to Section 382, as a result of the change
in control in 2003, we believe our annual limitation on the use of our NOLs is $11.3 million.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Our total provision for income taxes in 2004, 2003 and 2002 were different from the amount expected by applying the statutory federal
income tax rate to the net loss.&nbsp; The approximate differences are as follows:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 17.&nbsp;RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS</font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We have a consulting agreement with Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. for governmental affairs services, primarily for advice on proposed
legislation and regulations and to advocate our interests before the U.S. Congress and regulatory agencies.&nbsp; Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. is controlled by John P. Venners, the brother of Theodore Venners, our Chairman and CEO.&nbsp; Prior to April&nbsp;1, 2004,
the agreement provided for monthly consulting fees of $12,000, reimbursement of expenses related to our business and certain performance-based bonuses.&nbsp; Effective April&nbsp;1, 2004, we negotiated a revised agreement with Venners &amp; Company, Ltd. for the
provision of these services at a fixed cost of $18,000 per month.&nbsp; Either party can terminate the agreement upon written notice.&nbsp; During the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, we paid Venners &amp; Company $198,000, $249,000 and
$149,000</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-27</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">respectively, in cash for consulting fees and $10,000, $58,000 and $58,000, respectively, for reimbursement of expenses, excluding certain bonuses.&nbsp; In 2003, we also issued Mr. John Venners 10,000 shares of our common
stock for services provided.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Venners and Company, Ltd. is one of the consulting firms, identified in Note 15 &ndash; Commitments and Contingencies above, which is
entitled to bonus compensation as a result of the passage of H.R. 4520 establishing certain tax credits.&nbsp; We are required to (i) make cash payments of approximately $25,000, (ii) extend the currently active consulting agreement for a period of 43 months at an
aggregate cost of approximately $323,000, (iii) issue 4,800 shares of common stock for services provided, and (iv) issue warrants for the purchase of 150,000 shares at an average exercise price of $7.35 per share with a term of three years.&nbsp; We expensed $25,000
in general and administrative expenses related to the issuance of common stock.&nbsp; The proceeds to us from the exercise of these warrants would be $1.1 million and the non-cash expense, based on the Black-Scholes option-pricing model (assuming a weighted average
risk free interest rate of 2.83%, expected option life of 3 years, expected volatility of 46.6% and no dividends), for issuing these warrants was $519,000.&nbsp; In addition, we recognized $25,000 of expense related to the issuance of common stock.&nbsp; As a result,
we recognized a total of $544,000 of general and administrative expense related to this success-based fee for the year ended December 31, 2004.&nbsp; While the expense was recognized in 2004, the issuance of stock did not occur until 2005.&nbsp; Lastly, the $25,000
cash payment was made in January 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In December 2004, KFL, our wholly owned subsidiary, entered into a licensing agreement with Cook Inlet Coal, an affiliate
of Kanturk Partners LLC, under which KFL agreed to license to Cook Inlet Coal its proprietary coal processing technology for use at a coal processing plant to be operated by Cook Inlet Coal.&nbsp; Kanturk Partners owns approximately a 12% interest in Cook Inlet
Coal.&nbsp; Mr. John Venners, brother of our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Theodore Venners, has an approximately 4.5% interest in Kanturk Partners.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, we are obligated to make licensing and royalty payments to a party related to Theodore Venners, our Chairman
and CEO.&nbsp; See further discussion in Note 7 &ndash; Prepaid Royalties and Note 15 &ndash; Commitments and Contingencies.</font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="left"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lastly, we entered into a series of transactions with certain investors between March&nbsp;28, 2002 and August&nbsp;21,
2002 to sell common stock and warrants.&nbsp; One of the investors received the right to select up to two persons to serve on our Board of Directors.&nbsp; As a result, Richard Spencer, Manager of Westcliff Capital Management LLC, was added to our Board of
Directors.&nbsp; See further discussion in Note 10 &ndash; Stockholders&rsquo; Equity.</font></p>

<p align="left"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">NOTE 18.&nbsp;SUBSEQUENT EVENTS</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In January 2005, the Board of Directors appointed Mr. Grady Rosier and Dr. Robert Kaplan to fill vacancies on the Board of
Directors.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On February 1, 2005, our former President and Chief Operating Officer, Mr. C. Scott Hobbs, resigned and was replaced by our new
President and Chief Operating Officer, Mr. Robert Hanfling.&nbsp; In March 2005, we hired William Laughlin as our General Counsel.&nbsp; See further discussion of these and other subsequent events in Note 11 &ndash; Stock Option Plans.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On March 15, 2005, we entered into a letter of intent to purchase the assets or membership interests of MR&amp;E, LLC, a private
research, engineering and project management firm focused on thermal process engineering, including the upgrading and processing of clean coal.&nbsp; The intended purchase price is approximately $500,000 and we expect the transaction to be consummated early in the
second quarter of 2005.&nbsp; If we purchase the membership interests of MR&amp;E, it will become a wholly owned subsidiary.&nbsp; We expect MR&amp;E will mange the operation of the 750,00-ton plant upon its completion.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">F-28</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Fourth Quarter 2004 Discussion</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We recognized a non-cash impairment charge during the fourth quarter of 2004 of $1.3 million related to certain site-specific and plant
size-specific costs incurred associated with our 750,000-ton plant.&nbsp; In addition, we incurred approximately $2.2 million in costs related to performance-based bonuses for the passage of legislation that was favorable to us.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Fourth Quarter 2003 Discussion</font></i></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We recognized a gain on disposal of our Pegasus operations in the fourth quarter of 2003, which created net income for the
quarter.&nbsp; Substantially all of the Company&rsquo;s revenues were derived from its discontinued Pegasus operating segment.&nbsp; Therefore, since our presentation excludes these operations, revenues and gross margin were not provided in this table.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
F-29</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-10.60
<SEQUENCE>2
<FILENAME>exh10-60.htm
<DESCRIPTION>WAIVER AGREEMENT DATED DECEMBER 17, 2004 BETWEEN KFX INC. AND THEODORE VENNERS
<TEXT>
<html>
<head>
<title>Exhibit 10.60</title>
</head>
<body link="blue" vlink="purple">
<div>
<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">Exhibit 10.60</font></b></p>

<p align="center"><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">WAIVER AGREEMENT</font></b></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This Waiver Agreement is entered into as of December 17, 2004 (the "<u>Effective Date</u>") by and among KFx Inc., a Delaware corporation (the
"<u>Company</u>"), and Theodore Venners, the Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of the Company ("<u>Venners</u>").</font></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHEREAS,</font></b><font size="3">a predecessor of the Company and Edward Koppleman, individually, as trustee of the Riverfront Trust, a Revocable Trust
dated December 31, 1980, as trustee of F.H. Prince Trust, a Revocable Trust dated September 5, 1979, and as General Partner of KGM Associates, a California Limited Partnership (collectively, "<u>Koppelman</u>"), are parties to that certain Royalty Agreement dated
December 29, 1992, as amended (the "<u>Royalty Agreement</u>") pursuant to which the Company agreed, among other things, to pay royalties to Koppelman in an amount equal to 25% of the license fee and royalty payments received by the Company under certain license
arrangements;&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHEREAS,</font></b><font size="3">capitalized terms used herein and not otherwise defined shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the Royalty
Agreement;</font></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHEREAS,</font></b><font size="3">the Company may pursue certain business transactions involving the licensing of its technology for purposes of K-Fuel
Production;</font></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHEREAS,</font></b><font size="3">such K-Fuel Production is expected to result in royalty payments payable to Koppelman's estate pursuant to the Royalty
Agreement (the "<u>Royalty Payments</u>");</font></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHEREAS,</font></b><font size="3">prior to his death, Koppelman bequeathed his rights to 50% of all Royalty Payments to Venners; and</font></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHEREAS,</font></b> <font size="3">Venners is a large shareholder in and CEO of the Company and wishes to waive his rights with respect to such Royalty
Payments to address any actual or apparent conflict of interest that may arise between him and the Company.</font></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; NOW, THEREFORE,</font></b> <font size="3">for good and valid consideration, the receipt and adequacy of which are hereby acknowledged, Venners hereby waives
all of his right, title and interest to any portion of the Royalty Payments payable to Koppelman's estate now or at any time in the future to the extent such Royalty Payments become payable as a result of the payments to the Company, K-Fuel LLC., a Delaware limited
liability company ("<u>K-Fuel LLC</u>") or any affiliated entities, pursuant to the K-Fuel Technology License Agreement dated as of December 17, 2004, between K-Fuel LLC and Cook Inlet Coal LLC, a Delaware limited liability company.&nbsp; The above referenced waived
Royalty Payments are referred to below as the "<u>Waived Payments</u>."</font></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In furtherance of the purpose of the foregoing waiver, Venners agrees to use his best efforts to cause Koppelman's estate to agree to the terms of this Waiver
Agreement, and to confirm in writing a reduction in the amount of Royalty Payments otherwise payable to&nbsp; Koppelman's estate by the Company in the amount of the Waived Payments.&nbsp; Regardless of the foregoing, Venners will prompt transfer to the Company any
Waived Payments he receives without any further consideration.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">-1-</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="4" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This Waiver Agreement and the rights and obligations hereunder shall apply to, bind and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective heirs,
executors, administrators, legal representatives, transferees, successors-in-interest and assigns.</font></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This Waiver Agreement may be executed in one or more original or facsimile counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and all of which together
shall constitute one and the same instrument.</font></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">[SIGNATURE PAGE FOLLOWS]</font></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
- -2-</font></p>

<div align="center"><font size="4" face="Times New Roman"></font>
<hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#999999" align="center" />
</div>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Company and Venners have executed this Waiver Agreement as of the date first above written.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><b><u><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">Company:</font></u></b></p>

<p><b><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">KFx INC.</font></b></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">By:&nbsp;<u>/s/ C. Scott Hobbs&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</u><br />
 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;C. Scott Hobbs<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;President and COO</font></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><b><u><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">Venners:</font></u></b></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><u><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;/s/ Theodore Venners&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></u><br />
<b>THEODORE VENNERS</b></p>

<p><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<DESCRIPTION>CONSENT OF DELOITTE & TOUCHE LLP
<TEXT>
<html>
<head>
<title>Exhibit 23.1</title>
</head>
<body>
<div>
<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Exhibit 23.1</font></b></p>

<p align="right"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></b></p>

<p><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM</font></b></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We consent to the incorporation by reference in Registration Statements on Form S-8 (Nos. 333-09873, 333-82357, and 333-106129) and Registration Statements on Form S-3 (Nos. 333-04298, 333-28129, 333-82455, 333-88211,
333-87774, 333-104677, 333-106207, and 333-121312), of our reports dated March 16, 2005, relating to the consolidated financial statements of KFx, Inc. and management&rsquo;s report on the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting of KFx Inc.,
appearing in this Annual Report on Form 10-K of KFx Inc. for the year ended December 31, 2004.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">DELOITTE &amp; TOUCHE LLP</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"></font></p>

March 16, 2005</font></p>
